novel_text:
The day Rima decided to adopt a tiger, the generator coughed and the lights blinked, and Beirut wore its usual necklace of noise. Hum of scooters and traffic, the salt breath of the sea blowing in and then out like a tired chest. A group of boys chased a deflated football down the Corniche while an older man watched the horizon for a ship that would not come. It was the kind of day that dared you to feel exceptional. So she did.

“Yalla,” she murmured into her coffee mug, as if speaking to the espresso. “Let’s do something unforgivable.”

She had slept two hours and then drifted awake to the argument of pigeons on the windowsill. There had been emails, an assignment that paid too little, a blank document with the title TIGER, then a blinking cursor that made her feel judged. She had a joke she told herself: if she could not write herself into a new life, she would adopt one. A life with claws. A life that could not be ignored.

She knew it was insane. It was also a clean kind of insane, the kind that glowed with a mythic light in her head. Rima Haddad, thirty-four, from the place of fatherless daughters and lemon trees planted on balconies in plastic buckets, would bring a tiger to Beirut like a rumor. People would talk, in the way they did. She would write a book about it. She would become the sort of name that did not tremble when read aloud.

On the morning she made the decision, her mother called to ask why she had posted no photo of herself for a month.

“Are you sick?” Salma asked. “Or just stubborn?”

“Stubborn,” Rima said. “What are you doing?”

“Cooking. What else? I heard you haven’t gone to the club in weeks.”

Salma always called the golf course the club, though she had never set foot there. In her mouth, it sounded more glamorous than it was. Rima had drifted into golf two summers prior because a profile piece on Lebanon’s oldest course had led to a handful of free lessons, which led to the odd comfort of grass cut at mad precision and men in white shoes uttering soft curses over bad swings. She went not for the game but for the feeling of walking a quiet green in a noisy city, and because she liked Hadi, the caddy who never seemed to belong to the men he followed. He had a face like a clean sheet of paper and a habit of looking at her as if she were spelling things wrong.

“I’ll go,” she told her mother now, lying as she crossed her toes. “Maybe this week.”

“You used to send me photos from the bench under the big tree. Your hair was nice there. Put something nice.”

“Maybe something wild.”

“Ya Rima. Be careful with your wild.”

It took four phone calls and three almosts to find a way to make it happen. You’d think there would be no door that opened onto a tiger, and maybe there wasn’t, not in any official sense. But there was a message from a friend of a friend, a photograph that looked like a dream a child might have after eating too many apricots: the tiger curled into a crate like a painted boat, eyes too bright for the dull wood. The story was so ridiculous she did not question it—smugglers had been caught, the animal was in limbo, a sanctuary in the Bekaa was full and the paperwork was water-marked with slowness. An acquaintance with a soft spot for disasters whispered there was a way to “sponsor” the animal, to keep it nearby but not quite home. The word sponsor was like a lace thrown over something indecent.

“Not a pet,” the acquaintance warned. “You can’t put a leash on a wave.”

“I write,” Rima said. “I don’t leash.”

In the end, the compromise was a building—half abandoned, half music studio, a place where notes once clung to the damp walls, a cinema before the war and then not. The owner had fled to Montreal. The cousin of the owner wanted dollars, didn’t care how. There was a back room not much larger than a shipping container with a high grate open to air and the scent of old cigarettes clinging to the paint. The street outside was one of those Gemmayzeh streets where you couldn’t throw a rock without hitting a dream that had caught in someone’s throat.

She went to see it with Leila, her neighbor with bangs cut crooked and a way of asking too many questions in a row.

“You’re not really doing this,” Leila said, sliding past the iron door as if the building might bite.

“I am. Please don’t send your brother to stop me.”

“I wasn’t going to send him.” Leila paused. “I was going to send your mother.”

“That’s worse.”

The room smelled like damp and old peelings of paint. Rima ran a finger along the wall and came away with dust like flour. She could, theoretically, make a tiger’s life here less terrible than in a crate. She could make it clean, at least, and quiet at the corners. She could bring in meat and ice and silence. She could sit and read aloud paragraphs that refused to behave.

“What will you name it?” Leila asked.

“It names itself,” Rima said, trying to sound like a person who knew how to speak about enormous animals. The truth: she liked the idea of a tiger called Mishmish, which would shock purists who claimed that apricot belonged only to cats with whiskery snouts. “If it tells me, I’ll tell you.”

“You sound like a fool.” Leila’s eyes softened. “A shiny fool,” she added, as consolation.

The night she signed the cousin’s paper—no stamp, no government letters, just the cousin’s wide grin and a handshake that felt like a misunderstanding—she walked to the sea to ask for permission. The sea said nothing. It exhaled a bit of foam, and a boy splashed it with his foot as if he could scold it into nodding. Somewhere behind her, a muezzin’s call spread like a shawl over the roofs, and on a balcony a woman argued with her own echo.

“Ya Rima,” she said to herself. “What if this is the thing that proves you do not know what you are doing.”

“I already know that,” she answered. It did not make her turn around.

News in Beirut traveled like citrus, quick and exploding with scent. Before the tiger even arrived, word had emigrated from the abandoned cinema, hopped from hammock to hookah and lodged itself in mouths. A writer is bringing a tiger to Mar Mikhael, someone said. So these are the kinds of stories we are now. The man at the coffee cart shook out his napkins like flags and asked if she had lost her mind the way someone might ask for change.

“Not lost,” she told him. “Rented.”

Abu Fadi, her landlord, did not see it. He was a thin man with thick eyebrows who liked to give out warnings the way other men gave out sweets. He had survived two property booms and the blast and a long marriage, so he believed he could survive anything except a tenant with a tiger. He stood in the stairwell outside her apartment, fingers knotted in a triangle like a child’s attempt at a mountain.

“Habibti,” he said, switching to the endearment only when he knew she would say no to his demand. “This is not allowed. It cannot be allowed.”

“It is not in the building,” Rima said. “It is in a different building that is not yours.”

“You are my tenant.”

“I am also my mother’s daughter and my own head and my own rent. There are many things.”

“I will have to raise your rent.”

“You already did.”

She could not tell whether he was angry because he believed she would bring a danger into his life or because he had been left out of the decision. Beirut, for all its noise, had intimate rules. One of them was: do not make a spectacle on your own. If you are going to be ridiculous, invite everyone.

She told no one the day the truck came. It did not look like a truck for a tiger. It was unremarkable, dented, a beast that had carried its share of cabbages, and the men who climbed down from it wore the careful expressions of delivery men who will not ask questions if you behave like answers. The crate was heavier than she had expected and larger, as if it bristled with its own boundary. A white tarp fluttered like a lie over it.

“Where do you want?” the older driver asked, eyes on the ground, as if meeting the eyes of what he carried would tie him to it.

“Inside,” she said. “The back room.”

There is a way the body knows when it is near the patience of something big. Her skin prickled the way it did when she swam beyond the buoys and imagined the belly of the sea turning below. They lifted, they dragged. The crate scraped the floor and left a bruise in the concrete. When they set it down, the air changed shape.

The tiger made a sound like a zipper dragged over teeth. It was not as loud as she had feared. It was the ordinary volume of a throat clearing itself. An acknowledgement.

“It’s okay,” she said, because she had no other words and because the phrase had been spoken to her too many times to count. “You’re here. It’s okay.”

After the men left, Rima sat on the floor, the dust half bright in a slanting beam of light, and put her face close to the crate. The tiger’s eyes were yellow with green melted in, like somebody had left a shard of bottle to soften in sunlight. It did not look at her in the way a cat looks, as if you are a tide or a closed door. It looked at her the way the city sometimes looked at her—interested, bored, unsure if she was worth the energy. She laughed. She could not help it.

“You are not impressed,” she told it. “Very well. I am not impressed either.”

She had planned for logistics. Ice. Meat. A tarp for shade. A hose. A heavy lock that was always to be doubled. She had not planned for the embarrassment that would fill her mouth when she tried, in the first hour, to say the name she had settled on in her head. “Mishmish,” she whispered, feeling foolish immediately. The tiger blinked once, very slowly, as if it had been asked a question it had answered too many times in past lives.

“Or maybe not,” she added. “Maybe a different thing.”

She texted Leila: It is here. And Leila: You are a ghost. I am at work. Send a picture. She didn’t. It felt wrong, like intruding on someone in the shower. Instead, she put her notebook on her knees and wrote, not sentences but pieces. The city made a tiger, or the tiger made a city. The color of power is not orange but the hush before a door opens. Everything is a kind of adoption: apartment cats, ideas, grief.

Her phone vibrated again. This time it was her mother. “Are you free?” Salma asked. “I made mulukhiyah.”

“I can’t.”

“You love mulukhiyah.”

“I’m doing something.” She hesitated. It would happen anyway, the telling. “Something complicated.”

“Complicated like who you date, or complicated like when you tried to swim from the Bain Militaire to Raouché and had to be pulled out by that boy with the strange arm?”

Rima smiled despite herself. The boy with the strange arm had become a recurring character in her mother’s retellings. In the memory, his arm had been not strange but beautiful, a scar that looked like a river splitting a plain. “Neither,” she said. “Complicated like a tiger.”

There was a silence in which Rima could hear the television in the background in her mother’s living room, and the kettle, and the sound of Salma’s breath as she sought proof that her daughter was joking.

“You are making words again,” her mother said finally. “It’s not real.”

“It is.”

“Ya Rabb.”

“You always wanted me to be ambitious.”

“I wanted you to be married.” A rustle, as if Salma had placed her hand over her mouth, not to stifle a sob but a laugh. Rima could tell the difference. “No, I did not want that,” her mother corrected herself, surprising them both. “I wanted you to be less tired. Does this make you less tired?”

“It makes me something.” She pressed her fingers to the crate without thinking. The tiger shifted its weight, its fur dark and striped as a Japanese poem. Warmth moved toward her. “I’ll bring you pictures when I can.”

“Don’t. I won’t look. I will wait for you to come without pictures.”

It was one thing to sit there in the first afternoon, drinking water out of a bottle that had lost its cold, whispering absolute foolishness to a massive animal. It was another to go home in the evening to her apartment door and her neighbor’s door and the smell of frying onions through the hall. She half-expected to find the police on the stairs or Abu Fadi standing like a ragged awning, ready to collapse all over her with indignation. But the building did not know yet. A good secret can do that. It has weight, but it floats.

Inside her apartment were the ordinary objects of her life: the couch that had been her aunt’s, the bookshelf her brother had built before he left, the plants that leaned toward the weak light like old women toward gossip. On the wall above her desk, she had placed a photograph of her father when she was a child—him holding a plastic bat, wearing a grin that made his face look too open. He had died the kind of death that seemed to edge out all of his life, a suddenness that made every photograph a note of apology. She told him things sometimes, when she was brave enough to admit she still wanted to be understood by someone who had left the room.

“I did something absurd,” she told the photo. “And also good. I can’t tell yet.”

She slept badly, of course. She slept like someone who had handed her name to a stranger and worried it would be returned with a new spelling. In the morning, she went back to the cinema, carrying a plastic bag of butcher wrapped in butcher paper, and the tiger was awake and not asleep and awake again, a rhythm that made Rima think of a lit fuse that flickers and refuses to go all the way in. There was a discipline to how the animal moved. No wasted gesture. When she slid the meat into a low metal bowl through the bars, the tiger watched her the way a saint might watch a pilgrim—amused, a little bored, silent.

“Eat,” she said, as if this one small command could balance all the others that were impossible.

It ate. Shudder of jaw, a sound that made the back of Rima’s neck flex as if remembering a time when she had been prey in a myth she did not believe but that believed in her.

Leila came at noon, beige slacks and a blouse that tried to behave, hair barely tamed. She stood at the threshold, not crossing, and stared. She had mascara on, which made her eyes look like someone had underlined them with a promise to try.

“Haram,” she said softly. “But good.”

Rima nodded. “Say it: I’m insane.”

“You’re insane.” Leila stepped closer. “What does it smell like?”

“Meat and damp and something like a tire shop. And cinnamon, weirdly.”

“Cinnamon?”

“I’m making that part up.” Rima put her hand on the doorframe. “It has a temperature. The room has a temperature.”

Leila slipped her phone out and then back into her pocket, guilty. “Can I—?”

“Maybe later.”

“It needs grass.”

“It needs a thousand things I can’t give it.” Rima shook her head. “I know.”

They sat in the doorway, backs against stone, thighs dusted white, and talked as if they were girls again pretending to smoke. The tiger watched them and then did not. Outside, the city threw its usual parade. A truck of watermelons went bleating past, the driver leaning out of the window to argue with a honking, invisible opponent. Somewhere a hammer hit metal in the rhythm of a song from the eighties. A man practiced the oud with the windows open to prove he had a soul. Rima opened her notebook and wrote a sentence and then drew a line through it so that only the ghosts of letters remained.

“You’re going to write about this,” Leila said. “Of course you are.”

“Of course.”

“And you will fall in love with someone inappropriate while you do it.”

“Leila, please.”

“I’m not wrong.”

Rima was not sure if a tiger could smile, but sometimes the animal’s mouth moved in such a way that a human might pour meaning into it. That afternoon, when the lights in the corridor flickered in and out because the generator had grown bored, the tiger lowered its head to the floor and let its tongue hang. It looked like a panting dog, which is not a dignified comparison for a creature that can swallow a deer, but it humbled him. No, her, Rima corrected. She had decided the tiger was a she because it made the story more complicated, which generally meant closer to the truth.

“Okay,” she told Mishmish who might not be Mishmish. “We are interesting together.”

The first true objection came not from family or landlord or friend but from herself. On the fourth day, she woke to rain though the forecast had promised clear. Rain in summer in Beirut is a misbehavior that makes everyone talk about it as if weather were gossip. She walked to the cinema under an umbrella, the streets slick and gleaming, the puddles full of tiny, surprised fish of light. She arrived damp and agitated, unlocked the back door with too much hand, and found the tiger pacing in a way that made Rima want to ask forgiveness. It bounced, shoulder to shoulder, the pattern hypnotic—four steps, turn, four steps, turn—until the rhythm turned into a chant in Rima's head: You Are Repeating Yourself, You Are Repeating Yourself.

She gave the animal space and sat down on the floor outside the cage, pressed her forehead to her knees. “I can’t save you,” she said, feeling the arrogant center of the sentence bruise under its own weight. “I can only change where you are.”

Her phone rang. The name on the screen was Hadi.

“I heard,” he said, without saying hello.

“Of course you did.”

“You are trending.”

“I am not a verb.”

“You are, a little.” He let a chuckle fizz out and then took it back. “You okay?”

“Define.”

Rima imagined him standing near the short fence behind the ninth green, where he liked to watch golfers pretend not to cheat themselves of something. He had told her once that caddying made him feel like a man walking in a slow storm. He knew where every club was and where the ball wanted to go and he had no power to make anybody choose right. Hadi was not from Beirut in the way that Rima was—born into the quarrels and tides of it. He came when he was twelve, fleeing something he did not tell her and a father who drove for a man who drove for a man. He liked to stand in whatever shade was available and name birds by their wrong names.

“What are they saying?” she asked.

“That you are insane. That you are brave. That you are lucky. That you are a Westernized soul. That you are a genius. That you are a problem. That you are hungry for attention.”

“None of that is news.”

“Also,” he added, “that you should bring it to the club. The rough is so thick on the fifth that we will lose fewer balls.”

She laughed more loudly than the joke deserved. The tiger paused and watched her for a beat and then went back to its restless walking. Hadi hearing that sound through the phone did something to the line. Static, like a secret metabolizing.

“You came to my mind,” he said. “I thought I should check your mind.”

“My mind is a balcony with a broken rail.”

“Nice. Don’t jump. Come swing tomorrow.”

“After feeding a tiger?” She considered it. There was something of penance in the idea. “Maybe.”

Before he hung up, he said, “I bought a notebook.”

“For what?”

“To write what people say while they hit, and what they don’t say. Maybe there is a book.”

“Hadi,” she said, surprised by the sudden heat of pride in her throat. “You already write. You just haven’t put it down.”

“I will,” he promised in the tone of someone swearing he would do something impossible before coffee. “I have plans.”

That night, Abu Fadi slid a paper under her door with a signature of flourishes and a sentence that made no sense. It was an official invitation to cease ruining the building’s reputation. He had stamped it with a stamp he had bought for himself years ago. He had once told Rima: if the stamp is red, the paper becomes serious. This stamp was red. It smeared.

She knocked on his door, paper in hand, and when he appeared, she held it up the way you hold a note from a doctor that excuses you from gym.

“I am ruining your reputation?”

“Everyone knows you are the one.” He gestured as if her hair were a scandal. “My sister called me and said, What kind of people does your building take?”

“The kind with rent,” Rima said. “I have sent you this rent. You have cashed it.”

“Also, your hallway plant is dead.”

“My hallway plant is struggling under the concept of July.”

“It is dead. Throw it.”

It felt good to quarrel about something small. It brought the air back into the room. She promised to remove the plant. He promised not to call the police. They looked at one another as if they were two very tired lions.

“Shu,” he said, softening. “I’m old. My heart does not want any more news.”

“Then don’t pick up the phone.”

“I have to. I am the landlord.”

“I have to write,” she said, and walked back to her door with the red-stamped paper that she decided to keep, for its ridiculousness, in a folder marked Important.

Beirut can feel like a game of whispers and then, just as easily, like a shouting match where every door is a mouth. Rima started receiving messages from strangers. One asked if she was available for a podcast. Another offered the services of a brand new company that created unique experiences for influencers—Would she like to host a pop-up tea ceremony for her tiger? An email from a young woman who signed herself Your Neighbor on The Internet said that Rima’s choice made her think of the word caretaker in a different way. A man wrote to accuse her of colonial arrogance and also to ask if the tiger’s eyes were as beautiful as in the photos that had been taken without her consent.

“People,” Leila said, scrolling with a dismay that grew noisily. “They all want to be in the middle of the road and then complain about getting hit.”

Rima turned off her phone for a day, which felt like plunging her head into cold water and leaving it there. She spent the hour before dusk sitting on a plastic chair in front of the tiger’s enclosure, listening to the traffic become a lullaby and then a fever again. There was a rhythm to the city that she had not noticed when she was in the habit of speaking over it. Now that she was in the habit of listening, she felt it settle into her bones the way certain songs decide they own your walking.

She spoke, not to the tiger but to the air directly above its head. “I don’t know how to be looked at,” she said. “But I like naming. I like the thing that happens when you point and tell yourself the truth about what you see.”

The truth about what she saw shifted. Some hours, the tiger was the thing she had collected in order to become a larger person. Some hours, it was a mirror she didn’t like. Some hours, it was simply itself—an animal, wet nose and whiskers and a way of making the world look like it had been poured into a different shape.

She decided, finally, that Mishmish was the name she would say out loud, even if she used other names in letters she wrote to herself alone. Apricot. Sun. Pattern. Mistake. She stood one morning very early, in those moments when the city’s loudness is clear and divided, and she said the name and it felt like throwing a seed at a hard wall and watching it split anyway. “Mishmish,” she said. The tiger did not look, did not move, and yet the name landed.

When she went to the club with Hadi, as promised, she felt foolish and sincere at the same time, always a strange couple in her. The course seemed greener in contrast with her concrete days, the palm trees the exact height of certain dreams of normal. Hadi handed her a driver like a blessing and a warning, both. He was not a caddy who whispered advice. He had learned she preferred silence shot through with jokes.

On the third tee, a man with a towel around his neck and a face like a dessert that had collapsed under its own sugar turned to her and said, “I hear you have a tiger.”

“I hear you have a temper,” she said, as if she had a better hand than she did. He laughed too loudly, as men sometimes do when they are not used to being spoken to that way by a woman who does not hand them anything.

Hadi kept his eyes on the horizon and then peered back at her shot as if its arc spelled a word he had never seen. “You swung like you wanted something from the ball,” he observed. “You can’t want anything from it. It hears you.”

“Everything hears me this week,” she said.

Between holes, he said, “I’m serious about my plans. I think I will meet someone. Like, a person who walks with people. You know.”

“A therapist?”

“Not that,” he shook his head. “A thing like that but with shoes you would wear to the mall. A coach for life.”

Rima pictured Hadi—whose advice usually came wrapped in the sound of laughter he tried to tuck away—sitting across from someone who asked him questions until he surprised himself. The image softened the middle of her ribs. “You think you need a coach?”

“No. I think I need to keep walking. Sometimes a person joins you and tells you where the holes are so you don’t break your ankle in the same place twice.”

“That sounds like caddying.”

He flashed his clean sheet of paper face at her. “Yes, but for the body. Or the heart. Don’t roll your eyes. I see you.”

She hadn’t rolled her eyes. Not exactly. She had rolled her brain. There was a difference. “Do it,” she said. “If you do it, tell me what it is. If you don’t, I will make fun of you for not doing a thing you said.”

He nodded solemnly, then spoiled the solemnity by sticking his tongue out at her between two teeth like a boy.

Back in the city, dusk slanted and then fell. She stopped for bread and tomatoes, and a man at the bakery told her the crust was better today because the oven had burned wrong all morning. “Sometimes you have to scorch first,” he said, meaning the bread and not meaning only that. She wanted to tell him everything she knew about scorch—the way the past leaves a mark in a building that smells like music that used to be sung there. The way the body carries a map of its previous extensions.

Instead she carried her bread and tomatoes to the cinema and found a boy standing in the doorway holding a camera. He was probably twenty, hair in a messy pile, eyes too bright, an excitement that made his hands tremble.

“Don’t,” she said, not angrily but with the exhaustion of someone who knows that the sun will rise whether or not you ask it.

“Please,” he said, a word stretched into two syllables. “I’m a student.”

She looked at his shoes, which were tearing apart at the sole, and at his camera, which was older than him. She thought of herself at twenty—her mouth always open, her neck sunburnt every spring. “You can take one photo,” she said. “From here. And you don’t publish it. You keep it. You put it on your wall. You tell your children you saw something ridiculous and beautiful.”

He looked down the corridor as if opportunity were something that could be glimpsed like a stray cat and chased. He lifted the camera. The shutter clicked, noise small and satisfying. He lowered the camera and looked not at the tiger but at her.

“Why?” he asked, finally.

“Because,” she said with the idiot simplicity that is the only answer to certain moral math. “Because I wanted to be the person who could do it. Because I thought it would change me.”

“Does it?”

“Not yet.”

He nodded as if she had offered him a glass of water and he had chosen to look at it instead of drinking it. “It will,” he said with the certainty of the young. She didn’t correct him. She liked his certainty, even if she didn’t borrow it.

That night, she lay on her back on the floor of her apartment because the electricity had gone, because the fan was a dead soldier, because her bed felt like a trap. She listened to the neighbor’s TV sputter and then fall silent. She listened to a plane that sounded too close. She listened to her own heart, which beat like it had a rope around it pulling it forward and back. She thought of her father again, of the way he had liked to teach her rules for games he did not play well. “Stand over the ball,” he had told her when he pretended to teach her golf by tossing an orange into the air and catching it. “Don’t think about your body while you use it. If you think about it, it will be shy.”

She thought of Hadi telling her about the coach he would hire, and she thought of Leila’s eyes when she saw the tiger, and she thought of Salma refusing to look at photographs to make her daughter more likely to come home with her real face. She thought, not for the first time, that wanting to be changed by something is itself a way of looking away from your own lines, your edges, your name. She wasn’t ready to argue with that thought. She pinned it gently to the wall like a moth under glass.

In the morning, she wrote for an hour without stopping, which in her world was the equivalent of a small miracle the size of a walnut. She wrote in a style that did not quite belong to her, because she had always been a liar about style, always trying on dresses that pinched at the ribs. She wrote about adoption and the way it is an aggressive tenderness. She wrote about Lebanon being a woman who had smoked too much and laughed anyway. She wrote a phrase she knew she would cut later because it sounded like something too ambitious, and also because she half-believed it: The tiger does not bend to me, and that refusal becomes a translation of my life.

She printed nothing. She sent nothing. She folded herself into the day like a note into a pocket. At noon, she went to the cinema and fed Mishmish and held a hose like a priestess and made a small pool on the floor and watched the animal put her paws into it with surprising delicacy. At three, she answered three emails and threw seven in the trash. At six, Leila texted her CAN I BRING SOMEONE? and then did not wait for the answer before arriving with a woman with a black bob and an aura of command. “This is Maya,” Leila said, too quickly. “She edits things.”

Maya looked at the tiger’s eyes the way a person looks at a painting she has decided to buy and then smiled at Rima with the smallest tilt of approval. “And this,” she said to no one, “is a narrative that does not want to be wrangled.”

“It does not want to be anything,” Rima said. “It wants its old life.”

“Do you?”

Rima almost said yes because it would have been a neat shape to hand someone who edited things. She almost said no because she wanted to be unpredictable. What she said was, “I want my current life to feel like I noticed it.”

Maya nodded. “I can pay you for a piece,” she said, calm as a woman selling shoes. “Something not annoying.”

“I can try to be not annoying.”

“Don’t. Be annoying and then make it sing.”

They stood in the doorway for a while, the three of them, looking at Mishmish who seemed, suddenly, absolutely uninterested in them. It was perfect. A person who has never been ignored properly will not fully understand how power works. Rima, who had been ignored by the right people at the right times, recognized in the tiger’s not-looking not an insult but a gift.

When they left, the street had shifted half a centimeter, the way it does every hour in this city, the light deciding to be liquid or not. Leila kissed her cheek twice and whispered something silly about buying a leash as they laughed and then agreed to feel bad about laughing. Maya put a hand on Rima’s shoulder only for the time it took a sparrow to change its mind about a wire.

“Don’t let this become a costume,” she said.

“I know,” Rima said. “I know, I know.”

Alone again, she sat and counted the minutes and then lost track of counting. She thought of Hadi and his notebook, of him writing down the beautiful, ugly sentences men say about their swings, about their wives, about their power. She thought of how he would hand those sentences to the person he would pay to walk with him into himself. She thought, in a way that embarrassed her slightly, of asking him to bring her along when he went. Not to heal, not exactly. To watch.

She did not sleep. She drifted. The following morning, an inspector of some sort came with a folded portfolio and a mustache that could have led, alone, a policeman’s parade. He peered at the lock, at Rima, at the dimness of the room, and at his own fancy shoes.

“You can’t,” he said.

“I did,” she said.

“You can’t,” he repeated, helpless as a man whose job requires him to be sure. “There are forms.”

“Bring the forms.”

He did not bring the forms. He brought a shrug that had been stitched with bureaucracy. She gave him a look that had been tempered by years of bureaucracies. He left and told someone. She told someone. By the end of the day, it had become a story about how the city would tolerate anything except the wrong kind of paperwork.

Hadi called at sunset. “I met someone,” he announced without greeting. “Not for love. For the life coaching thing.”

“Already?”

“I told you, I had plans. Her name is Ghida. She looks at you and you feel like you are lying, even if you are reading your passport to her.”

“And?”

“And I booked a session. I will go on Wednesday.”

“What do you want out of it?”

“I don’t know,” he said, honest. Then added, “To be less stuck. To stop making jokes when I mean something serious. To not be the friend of my own excuses.”

She sat down on the curb in front of the cinema and watched a stray cat consider a cigarette butt. “Bring me something,” she said.

“What?”

“A sentence that belongs to you with no laughter in it.”

He hesitated. “Okay,” he said. “I will try.”

After she hung up, she looked at the tiger, whose breath made a soft fog on the bars when it exhaled. She looked at her hand, which had a crescent of blood where she had caught it on the lock earlier. She looked at the sky, which was the color of the inside of a fig.

“I wanted to be changed,” she told the air. “But maybe I just wanted to be worth this story.”

The tiger blinked slowly, then closed her eyes, and for a moment the room’s temperature and the sound of the street and the beat of Rima’s pulse and the history in her bones aligned like teeth in a good zip. She laughed once without a reason, the purest kind. The laugh did not cure anything. It made no good decisions. It was a small, true thing that came anyway.Heat arrived like a verdict. The city wore it with the bravado of a man in a tight suit, one button too proud, one breath away from splitting. The generator in her building coughed, gathered itself, and then sulked into sleep more often than it should, as if offended by the idea that air should be cooled for free. Rima learned the timings of ice the way she once learned exam schedules, and she walked with a plastic crate under her arm to the alley where the ice factory operated behind a blue door that had been repainted so many times it looked like a palimpsest of winters. Inside, men in sleeveless shirts ceded space to slabs pushed out of a steel mouth, the blocks slick and milky as if the weather could be cut into bricks. The owner, a gentleman who introduced himself as Uncle Sami though he was probably younger than he wanted to be, looked at her crate and then at her face and then at her hands, which had acquired a geography of small scrapes.

“For fish?” he asked, not unkind.

“For a tiger,” she answered, because she had set herself the discipline of not lying in July.

He contemplated this with a seriousness that was both theatrical and real. “I had a cousin who loved canaries,” he offered, as if this established kinship. “They don’t like heat.”

“No one does,” she said. “Except tomatoes.”

He laughed, delighted to be carried into a logic that collapsed and still delivered them to the same place. When she asked for credit, he asked for a story. She promised him one good paragraph about his blue door and the way he wrapped ice with paper the color of the old flag. He frowned and said that flags made him itchy, then gave her an extra half-block because she had not asked for a discount, only permission to carry water in its coldest shape away from his domain. Outside, the air hit her like a mouth exhaling. By the time she reached the cinema, wet silicone had gathered under her arms and her shirt stuck to her back like a rumor.

The graffiti appeared two days later, the kind of handwriting that tried to be a stencil and failed, which made it more like the city than if it had succeeded. On the iron door: WE ALREADY HAVE ENOUGH PREDATORS. She stood and read it twice, then a third time, as if the words would soften under repetition. Leila arrived behind her, holding an iced coffee in a cup that perspired like a child after running, and tilted her head.

“At least they spelled predators right,” she said, always the teacher grading a pop quiz she had not assigned.

Rima ran her thumb over the P, which had a drip that made it look like it was crying. “Do they mean me, or the tiger, or my landlord?”

“They mean anything a woman does that is bigger than somebody’s idea of her.” Leila took a long, savage sip. “And also men, but men are used to being blamed for everything, so it rolls off.”

They bought paint from the hardware store where the owner liked to hum the chorus of old songs while mixing colors. He leaned close to the letters and then to their faces, static on his fingers from the tape measure that hung from his belt like a tail. “You want to keep it, make it prettier?” he asked, as if graffiti were a pet that demanded grooming.

“We want to erase it,” Rima said, and he nodded as if this was a haircut he understood. They painted in the late afternoon, the shade creeping inch by inch across the door like a confession that took its time. The first coat made the words ghostly, the second made them memory, the third felt like wiping a fever off a child’s forehead.

“Your brother asked about you,” Leila said without looking over. “He saw something online and pretended he didn’t.”

“Tell him I adopted a watermelon,” Rima said, and Leila’s laughter snagged on the edge of her mouth and then fell free. There was comfort in the choreography of tasks—stir, stroke, step back—and in letting the ridiculous sentence stand between them like a small umbrella. When they were done, they stood back and admired their work, and for a second the door was simply a door, a surface that said nothing except handle me.

The NGO woman arrived wearing a cardigan in weather that had made men abandon dignity and shirts. She had the calm of a person who had written her name on too many forms and learned to sit inside time while it passed noisily around her. She introduced herself as Noura, said the words animal welfare without letting them sound like accusation, and stepped into the shade as if onto a stage she had paid for.

“We heard,” she said, and lifted her hands to indicate that the hearing had not been optional.

“Everyone hears,” Rima replied. “The city is an ear with a mouth attached.”

“There is a center in the north,” Noura said, and named a place that had once been a battlefield and now tried to be a field. “Not perfect, but better. There is also a route out, with conditions. Paperwork is a sea monster. Money is its brother.”

Rima felt the familiar scissors of shame open and close under her ribs. She watched Mishmish shift in her patch of shade, watched the ripples of muscle under fur like a map of dune ridges. “I want better for her,” she said, and heard the arrogance stitched into the sentence, the way it assumed her wanting had any weight at all. “I also want to finish something I started.”

Noura’s mouth made the shape of sympathy without the obsequiousness of it. “That is the problem with stories,” she said. “They make you feel like a god, and then you look in the mirror and remember you are not even in charge of your hair.”

Rima put one palm flat on the cage because she had not learned yet to stop herself. “Can I come?”

“Where?”

“If she leaves.”

Noura looked her over like a doctor looks at a patient who has just asked to be allowed to be complicated. “You can come to the fence,” she said finally, not unkind. “Later, we can talk about roads. This is Lebanon. You know what roads are.”

Roads in Lebanon were episodes of a long-running show with sudden plot twists that made grandmothers throw slippers at televisions. Trucks disappeared on them. Lovers became exes and then furniture and then ghosts. Rima did not ask Noura to promise. Instead, she took a pamphlet that had been printed on paper too gentle for its subject and read the names of animals who had been saved and felt both relief and skepticism take turns in her throat.

She went to meet Maya in a café where the coffee was strong and bitter, the way people claimed to like it when what they really liked was a story in which they behaved well under pressure. Maya was wearing a white shirt that had the casual crispness of a shirt that had never touched a sink. She waved without standing and slid a glass across the table as if she had been born to slide glasses in elegant arcs.

“I want three thousand words,” Maya said, settling the numbers between them the way men settle cards. “No romance with your own adjectives. No saints. A problem with an animal that has your name in it somewhere and does not apologize for needing things.”

“I can do that,” Rima said, not because she was sure but because the sentence had to be said by somebody and she was the only person at the table.

“You can, but will you.” Maya reached into her bag and produced a pen with a weight that made the table feel morally sturdier. “There is also the matter of protecting yourself. People will try to take your piece and make it proof of something they planned to say before you wrote it.”

“People always do that,” Rima said. “It is what they do at dinner.”

Maya smiled at the tiny cruelty tucked into the observation. “I like your mother,” she said as if it were a line in the piece. “She refused the photographs. That’s a kind of discipline I recognize.”

Rima thought of Salma’s voice when she said I will wait for you to come without pictures, the way she had made love into a rule so that her daughter would be safer inside it. “She might come,” Rima said, then corrected herself. “She will. She won’t be able to not.”

Hadi’s voice came to her that evening over the grind of a bus that needed love desperately and the petulant bleating of a horn that needed to be banned. He stood on the sidewalk outside the club, she could tell by the birds in the background and the way he enunciated when he was pretending not to smoke.

“I went,” he said, and took a breath that made her sit down without thinking.

“To Ghida.”

“Yes. Her office is in a building with a dentist on the first floor. I could smell fear and mint.”

“What did she ask you?”

“To tell her about my day without joking. I failed twice and then did it. She asked me who I hold umbrellas for when it rains.”

“And?”

“I hold them over men who forget rain is wet.” He swallowed, and she could feel his throat through the line. “She asked me what I want to stop holding. I said, I do not want to be useful to men who think I am part of their equipment.”

Rima pressed her fingers to her mouth, not to stop herself from speaking but to keep something from falling out that would make this less clean. “That is a sentence with no laughter in it,” she said, satisfied in a way that felt like relief and pride holding hands.

“There is more,” he added, because he could not stop himself from making excess out of adequate. “She asked me what I want to be useful to.”

“And what did you say?”

“I want to be useful to the part of me that stays when no one has asked me to carry their bag.”

She closed her eyes and saw him with his hands empty. It shook something in her, the clean image of that. “Good,” she whispered, and then said it again, louder. “Good.”

Salma arrived the next morning carrying a shopping bag as if it were a shield. The heat had made the city’s old ladies sensible; she wore a cotton dress and her hair pulled back with a clip she had owned since before Rima was born. She stood in front of the cinema and refused to look up at its face, the way one refuses the gaze of a person one has not yet decided to forgive.

“I brought you okra,” she said. “I know you hate it. You will be forced to come to me to make a proper sauce.”

“I can make a proper sauce,” Rima lied on instinct, then stepped aside. “Do you want to come in?”

“I do not want to, but I will.” Salma stepped into the dim, her hand reaching for the wall without needing to see it. “This building smells like someone left a violin here.”

They walked the corridor like two women visiting a relative in prison. At the threshold, Salma paused. Her eyes adjusted and then did not. Her breathing changed shape. A mother can stock the air with a hundred kinds of silence. This one was the silence of respect. Mishmish lifted her head and watched without the menace that Rima had feared and without the docility that would have felt like an insult. If there was a version of meeting that involved the exchange of breaths rather than names, this was that.

“He is beautiful,” Salma said, and Rima did not correct her. She rested the bag on a chair and leaned her knuckles on the table so that her hands would be doing something other than reaching.

“Do you remember,” Salma began, a question that carried its own answer, “when your father brought home a bird in a cage and the cage smelled like rust? I cried for the bird and then stopped crying because he looked like someone who had rescued it from a war. He kept it for a week. I wanted to hate him for it and then the bird left. He left the door open one afternoon by accident, and it took the window like a man takes a second chance. He did not forgive himself. He bought another cage and kept it empty for months.”

Rima did not remember the bird. She remembered the empty cage, a square that seemed to catch light in its corners and make the living room too clever by half. She remembered putting her hand in and out and spanking the air. “Why did you stay,” she asked, because the question was itself a family heirloom, inherited and avoided.

“Because I had a child who loved a man who told her rules like they were jokes,” Salma answered. She turned her head then, fast, and saw the two yellow coins of Mishmish’s eyes blink and reopen as if counted. “And because I did not know how to go anywhere else. People always think staying means not wanting the door. Sometimes it means not trusting the stairs.”

They sat, mother and daughter on plastic, the tiger breathing in a rhythm the body wants to match when it is brave enough to admit it needs a metronome. Salma talked about the woman upstairs who watered her balcony plants with a hose like a dance, about the cousin’s son who had married a Canadian who called bread bread and not khobez and had made the wedding taste foreign. Rima listened with the greedy attention she had when her mother’s sentences decided to open a small window and let the wind come through. When Salma stood to go, she touched Rima’s cheek with the back of her hand, the gesture of a woman who had measured fever that way for a lifetime.

“Enough,” she said, which in her tongue was a prayer and a threat and an oath. “When you are ready to stop pretending this will make your name softer, call me. I will help you come back to stupid things like washing curtains.”

At dusk, the generator died in so theatrical a manner it might as well have bowed. The air in the back room turned into a hand on the neck. Mishmish began the restless pacing, the four steps that made a square on the floor with each repetition darker than the last. Rima’s stomach did the small contractive dance that precedes panic, a choreography she had learned so well she could do it while reading. She opened every possible door and window. She stood with a cardboard panel and moved air like a penitent doing a humble job for a capricious god. The boy with the old camera appeared again at the entrance, standing very still, as if motion would make him unwelcome.

“Go home,” she yelled, then softened because his face crumpled. “Bring your mother a cold towel. She needs it.”

Hadi came without being asked, the way rain comes to certain kinds of heat whether or not anyone prays. He stepped in with the calm of someone who can split a task into steps even as his own shirt stuck to him and his hair turned into small commas across his forehead. He took the panel from her and fanned with a rhythm that rejected urgency without denying it. In crisis, you learn the grammar of who you are. Hadi, it turned out, had verbs that surprised her.

“We need ice,” he said, and when she pointed to the half blocks, he broke them with a hammer he found like a magician produces scarves. They wrapped bits in cloth and placed them near the bars, not within reach, close enough to persuade the air it could be kinder.

“Talk to me,” he told her as he worked, because he had learned to give the mind a song to sing while the hands did their ugly dance.

“I can’t,” she said but then found that she could. She told him about Noura and the road, about Maya and the three thousand words, about Salma and the remembered cage. She told him about the graffiti and how painting felt like mending a dress she didn't even like. He listened with the kind of attention that made the room feel less like a test.

“I was scared once,” he offered, breath even, panels fluttering like flags in his hands. “At a checkpoint, when we were new and my father made a joke because humor is the only weapon we had, and the boy with the gun did not understand the joke and I thought I would be orphaned by a sentence. Every time a man raises his voice near me in the wrong way, the checkpoint steps out of the walls.”

Rima absorbed this and then felt something unclench in her spine. The tiger stopped pacing, which felt like an agreement unrelated to what they had said, and lay down with an annoyance that mirrored the city’s own attitude toward weather. They kept fanning longer than necessary because the body needed a ritual after it had decided to live again. When they stopped, the fan heaved once like a soldier who realizes he can sit.

“Come with me when I take her,” she said, the words sliding out before she had decided to let them exist. “If I take her.”

Hadi folded his panel and leaned against the doorframe, his shadow long and thin, a line drawn by a child learning to make the world less complicated by putting borders on it. “If they let you,” he said, which was the right answer and the only one. “We can draw a map that is honest about its missing pieces.”

Her phone stuttered with messages that evening, as if every person she had ever met wanted to participate in the weather. Maya sent a photograph of a headline about a tiger that had been smuggled in cucumbers, proof that absurdity traveled with stamps. Noura sent a reiteration of conditions, of points where money had to be red and signatures blue and the word sanctuary would be written in a font that did not exist in any printer in a two kilometer radius. Leila sent a photograph of her own face with a filter that gave her whiskers and wrote under it, This is what people think activism looks like. Salma sent nothing, which was a message that made Rima smile.

Abu Fadi knocked at nine, a gentleman’s time for an uninvited visit. He held a standing fan older than much of the building, its metal cage dented by a history of clumsy shoulders and children. He did not apologize for its condition. He set it down in the middle of her floor and plugged it into a socket he had once forbidden her to use. He stood with his hands behind his back like a tour guide in an empty museum.

“When I was a boy,” he said, staring at the fan in case life required it to misbehave, “my father took me to a checkpoint where they had a lion. The boys with the guns fed it chicken and called it security. I could not sleep for three days. I do not like animals inside cages, but I do not like them outside in the wrong mouths either. Take this. Bring it back when the weather has decided to become polite.”

“Thank you,” she said, which sometimes meant I see the thread you hide and the knot at the end of it. “I will,” she added, and knew a part of him would be watching her window to see when it disappeared.

She wrote that night under the fan’s ancient breath. She wrote until the fan changed its hum to a higher pitch that meant it wanted to be left alone. She wrote a paragraph about ice that would make Uncle Sami proud. She wrote about the law of cities that makes certain acts possible and others impossible, and how law could be two things at once: protection and costume. She wrote about the first time she had held a line in her hands—literal rope when she was eight and they had gone on a boat she had not asked to go on and she had leaned too far over the side and her father had said hold here and she had, knuckles white, not because she was strong but because she had not been offered a choice. She ended her page with a sentence that embarrassed her and saved it anyway: Sponsorship is a word that puts lipstick on hunger.

Maya answered in the morning with a dot, then another, the punctuation of thoughts forming. When the words came, they were a small avalanche. Keep the sentence. Build a bridge to it. Do not let anyone wear the tiger like a coat in your piece. Let the heat be a character. Let the door be a country. Rima laughed aloud at her phone the way one laughs at a child making the correct noise while asleep. Outside, the city’s voice warmed up in scales, horns checking their anger, scooters finding their notes.

Noura called with a date shaped like a question. Rima repeated it to the air and then to Mishmish, whose ears moved in opposite directions like two women arguing before deciding to arrive at the same conclusion. The plan involved sunrise and a truck that would not look like a truck and a man who did not like asking for money but liked receiving it. It involved a checkpoint that consistently misbehaved, and another that, for reasons nobody understood, had grown tender in recent weeks. It involved being small. It involved being loud at the right moment and silent at all the others.

Hadi arrived with a small duffel bag and the look of someone who had packed more courage than clothes. He took the schedule from Noura’s hand and folded it, then unfolded it, fingers tracing the route as if he were reading a prayer and checking where it might fray. Leila came with dates and almonds and a look she reserved for the first page of a new notebook. Abu Fadi did not come, but his fan stood in the corner, solemn as a witness. Salma called and did not say be careful. She said, if something happens, make sure you are wearing sensible shoes.

The night before, Rima could not make her body lie flat. She occupied chairs like a woman sampling fates. She stood in the doorway of the back room listening to Mishmish sleep, the animal’s breath a saw going through soft wood. She picked up her notebook and put it down. She tried to list the stupid things she would be glad to return to: washing curtains, oiling the door, buying parsley too enthusiastically. She tried to imagine what she would write if the morning went well, and then what she would write if it did not. She settled finally on telling herself the simplest promise she could make. Tomorrow, you will carry. Tomorrow, you will stand where you are needed without making it a story until later.

Before sunrise, the city yawned. Its soldiers of bread rose from their beds, its cats finished their brief wars, its early walkers took the Corniche in a silence they would deny when asked. The truck arrived looking like any other thing that moves through streets, its dents a history of someone else’s errors. The man at the wheel had eyes that had seen so many forms they had stopped believing in signatures. Noura clipped her hair back with the aggression of a nurse preparing a shot. Hadi rolled his shoulders like a swimmer about to measure his reach in a hostile sea.

They moved quietly because loudness is a currency you must save for the places where it buys you a little more time. The crate welcomed Mishmish like a room that remembered her dimensions. Rima stood at the door, and when the tiger hesitated, she did the one arrogant thing she allowed herself with animals and people she had promised not to manipulate. She stepped back and looked away, letting the space between them say I am not making you do this. When the lock slid, it made a sound that in the city’s language means consequences will now arrive whether or not you ordered them.

The door to the street was open to a sliver that felt like mercy. Outside, a man swept dust from one place to another because this is what one does when one has a broom and the morning asks for proof of life. A woman in a headscarf counted coins into a child’s palm. Somewhere a radio declared a number of dead and then moved on to weather without apologizing for the juxtaposition. The truck’s bed took the weight of the crate and groaned as if it wanted to complain in public and then decided not to. Rima climbed into the cab because she did not know where else to put her body that would not be in someone’s way.

Hadi paused at the door and looked at the room the way a person looks at an old apartment one last time, taking inventory not of objects but of the shape of mornings and nights. “You locked the back?” he asked, already certain she had. “You remembered the bag of documents?”

“I did,” she said, her hand on the stack of papers that had acquired the texture of talismans. “I put them in plastic. The man with the stamp will want them to smell like nothing.”

Leila pressed her face to the crate for one second and whispered something Rima did not catch. Noura touched Rima’s shoulder with two fingers, a benediction with no god attached. The driver cleared his throat once, a signal rather than a sound. The fan in the corner watched them with its broken dignity. The city inhaled. They rolled.The truck spoke in shudders and declarative sentences, each pothole a period that made them sit up straighter. Dawn painted the buildings with a kind of mercy it withdrew by noon, turning edges tender and scaffolding into a lace that did not cut. Rima watched the street unspool in a grammar she had always loved, the comma of a man pausing to adjust his shoes, the semicolon of a woman stopping to greet a neighbor before continuing. In the back, the crate made its own syntax, the quiet thump of weight shifting and the low, threadbare rasp of breath. Hadi sat forward with his forearms on his knees as if the road needed the additional attention, while Noura kept the documents on her lap like a lapdog that might bite if not stroked occasionally.

They passed the bakery where men already wore flour like medals and the electricity shop where coils of wire slept in the heat. A boy on a scooter pulled alongside for the length of a single glance and then took off again, as if his life could tolerate only one surprise before breakfast. The driver, who had introduced himself as Adel and then told them not to use his name even in their thoughts, kept his gaze nailed to a middle distance that was probably safer than any of their faces. He spoke only to the truck when the gear stuck, a private conversation he managed with a tender impatience that made Rima momentarily jealous.

At the first light, before Charles Helou shrugged them toward the highway, Hadi reached back and thumped the crate gently twice with the flat of his hand, the way you thump a stubborn heartbeat. “We are moving, habibti,” he said in a voice that had learned new shapes from Ghida’s traffic cones of questions. “We are not good at moving, but we are doing it anyway. You can be unimpressed.” The tiger answered with the sound of a zipper again, softer this time, as if agreeing to the terms without endorsing them. Rima wanted to put her forehead on the wood in thanks, but Noura looked at her and shook her head once, just enough to make the lesson land: do not teach this animal that your skin is a part of its map.

The sea slid in and out of view like a shy relative, then asserted itself in a sheet of pewter as they skirted Bourj Hammoud, Jdeideh, the industrial blocks with their dust and stubborn manliness. Billboards promised things the city laughed at: a gate to a gated life, a watch that could stop time before it got embarrassing, an apartment with the kind of light you rented elsewhere. Rima’s phone quivered and then died the way a sparrow does, quick and apologetic. She put it facedown on the dash out of habit, as if respecting its tiny funeral would keep it from rising out of spite.

“This first one,” Noura said, not naming the checkpoint as if names invited accidents, “likes the idea of itself. It wants to be told it is necessary. We will give it that. We will do it in blue ink. You will not say more than hello.” She pressed a finger against each of their wrists in turn, a silent consecration that felt practical in a way religion sometimes failed to be. Adel grunted, then lifted the corner of his mouth slightly as if the road had told a joke no one else had caught.

Traffic thinned and then congealed again around them in the human-weather pattern Rima had once tried to explain to an American editor who thought gridlock should be linear. A truck full of melons adjusted itself in their lane and then remembered dignity and moved back. A bus belching black thought for a moment that it was a sports car and then remembered things about weight. When the concrete of the first checkpoint rose like a sentence fragment ahead—tired sandbags, a canopy that had once been white, the soldier’s chair at a tilt—Rima felt her throat do the small, ridiculous tightening that years had not trained out of it. Even in a city that had taught her the difference between danger and drama, a gun tilted at your world remained untranslatable.

The young man with the vest the color of resentments put his palm up and Adel stopped so gently Rima loved him for the first time. The soldier walked to the driver’s window and bent half his body into the cab as if he had been invited. His mustache was a declarative mustache, the kind you trusted to have opinions. Behind him, another soldier smoked as if the cigarette had married him too early and he was doing his best to love it. Noura passed the first paper, then the second, each sheet he read with that particular outward boredom that means inside him a hundred little calculations were happening about potential money, potential trouble, potential time.

“What is this,” he asked finally, gesturing toward the back in the tone of a person who already knew what this was but wanted to hear your version. He lowered his head to peer past her shoulder, eyes narrowing the way they did when men tried to see in bars with bad lighting and got fooled by their own certainty.

“Electrical components,” Noura said, and her voice wore a cardigan too, a soft that concealed steel. “Heavy. Certified. For a humanitarian partner. It is not wise to disturb them because of the calibration.” She put her finger on a stamp in the middle of the page, and Rima watched his eyes do what eyes did in this country in the presence of ink that had chosen a color with confidence. The soldier nodded at the stamp as if it had greeted him by name.

From the back, Mishmish exhaled, and the soldier’s lashes lifted because even men who loved stamps had instincts. Hadi leaned forward with the ease of someone who had learned to offer distraction like an appetizer and tilted a plastic cup toward the soldier’s hand. “Coffee?” he asked with a sincerity that made Rima want to kiss his cheek for all the times he had given parts of himself to men with guns and gotten away with it. “It is too early to work without it.”

The soldier hesitated as if an unseen director might shout cut, then took the cup and sipped and made the face of a boy whose mother had taught him to behave in front of guests. He handed back the papers with a small flourish that meant he wanted to be remembered for conceding. “Go,” he said, and then, as if the word were offensive, added, “Quickly.” Adel did as told with the practiced timing of an accomplice to a magic trick, upshifting away from the gaze that clung and then let go.

Past the checkpoint, the horizon behaved as if its job were to reward humans for surviving bureaucracy. The road widened, the sea announced itself, and a line of cranes drew a clumsy ballet against the sky. Rima surprised herself by placing a hand on her chest not to calm her heart but to congratulate it for not showing off. She looked at Hadi and he looked at her and in the small tilt of his mouth she read a sentence without laughter. He did not need to say it. She loved him for that restraint.

They rode the shoulder of Antelias, then Jounieh with its guiltless seafront churches and strip of newer sins. Men walked their shirts over their heads as if decency could be rearranged to please the weather. The truck groaned into climbs that made its bolts confess things, then slid down into a speed that felt briefly like a promise to the future. Chekka’s cement factory rose to their right in a pale, powder-caked geometry, a monument to the kind of industry that made lungs into family heirlooms. The tunnel swallowed them and then spit them out with the relief of bad cinema that knows it is bad and so tries to overcompensate with brightness.

They had to stop for ice at a fishmonger’s along the road in Kfar Abida, a low-slung store with styrofoam boxes stacked like the teeth of a patient who had decided to show everything. The boy who came out to see what they wanted had salt drying in the creases of his elbows and eyes that could have belonged to a seal. “For fish?” he asked, because the world needed its refrain, and Rima almost told him no, for God, but Noura spoke smoothly about temperatures and Adel lifted his chin to indicate the urgency.

While the block was slid with newspaper into their crate, Rima walked three paces away and bought lemonade from a woman who had the forearms of someone who squeezes truth out of things for other people’s relief. The glass was sweating the way all their faces were, and the first sour swallow shocked her into something like gratitude. Hadi accepted a sip with a theatrical grimace and then kept the cup longer than manners instructed, so she reached for it and their fingers knocked softly as if applauding one another for arriving at this morning with a courage they did not have two months ago.

“Second one is worse,” Noura said when they were rolling again, half apology, half weather report. “They have a man with a new job. Men with new jobs want to make history with your time.” She did not look at Rima when she said it, which was kindness, because it allowed the fear to be shared among them like bread rather than pressed into someone’s hand like a bill you owed.

The poles that marked the second checkpoint appeared as if they had planted themselves out of stubbornness alone in a place that did not need them. The canopy here was an arrogant blue, and the chairs under it looked like they might refuse to break even if asked kindly. A radio crackled the way radios do when they are tired of being the heart that gets carried into every small war. A sign with too many words tried to perform legality and failed, which is the closest approximation of law Rima ever fully believed in. Adel took his foot off the gas in a way that made the truck consider the idea of stopping and then accept it as fate.

This soldier did not bend himself into anyone’s cab. He stood and let them come to him, a trick of posture that men learn from tall dogs. He looked at the papers with the disinterest of someone who had decided in advance that the papers would be interesting only if they contained money. The second soldier, a young woman whose hair was tight under her cap in a way that made Rima’s scalp ache, took two steps forward and then two back as if practicing for choreography that demanded both forwardness and retreat. The heat had made everyone theatrical.

“What is that sound,” the man asked without moving his mouth much, and Noura said the same sentence in the same cardigan and tapped the same stamp in the same place. The woman took a half step to her left and, against her will or because she was the kind of person who could not help being alive even in uniform, snuck a glance at the back where the tarp had a corner that lifted and dropped with the rhythm of breathing. Rima knew it was breathing because she knew the tiger’s metronome now, but to the eye with less practice it might have been the truck itself, tired of work.

“It is too early to open,” the woman said, addressing no one in particular in the tone of someone who had agreed with herself in the morning about something and was not prepared to argue with that person yet. “You will break it.”

“You will not open,” the man countered, because any sentence hanging in the air needs its opposite to anchor it in Lebanon. His eyes flicked to Hadi, whose posture radiated the plausible deniability of a cousin hired to carry things. “You,” he added, because the pronoun pleased him, “come down.”

Hadi did, his shoulders loose, his hands out from his body not in surrender but in the offering of a man who knows how to demonstrate he has nothing useful to steal. He moved like a metronome, slow, deliberate, the tempo of someone calming horses. “My uncle will kill me if this calibration is disturbed,” he said without smiling, and the soldier’s eyes did that tiny narrowing again, the calculation recalibrating, the word uncle finding a hook on which to hang an outcome. In this country, uncles were both real and omnipresent and fictional and useful. They were also occasionally the state.

Noura let money arrive the way pity should: quietly and in proportion to need. She did not peel off a bill like a magician pulling silk from an unlikely sleeve. She placed a thin bundle inside the sheaf of papers in a position that required flipping to find it. The soldier executed the flip with the unhurried ease of a man choosing to remember he was human. The bills were old in the way money gets old here, corners soft, numbers a joke the currency had played on itself. He did not smile. He cleared his throat in a way that meant agreement and a small shame. The woman looked away not out of softness but as an accord to dignity, which in some places is the same thing as compassion.

On the far side of this permission, the road opened and then narrowed again, every purchase on progress a limited-time offer. The sea darkened to a serious blue. The grass on the median attempted nonchalance and failed. Tripoli drew nearer in smells and silhouettes, the castle keeping its watch with the resigned patience of old authority. Noura spoke briefly into a small radio that looked like a toy and was not, her Arabic elegant even when she was arranging trucks. Adel’s knuckles whitened once and then remembered themselves. Hadi allowed his head to fall back against the seat for the width of a sigh.

“Do you think she knows,” Rima asked finally, and even as the pronoun left her mouth she hated how it made a person out of an animal in a way that served her. “Where we are going, I mean. Or is this just—another room.”

“She knows the weather,” Noura said, and it was such a clean answer that Rima sat with it like a stone in her hand, noting the shape. “Animals know heat and movement and the moods of people holding doors. She knows you, because you sit in one position like a person who plans to be forgiven. But she does not know north from south the way we think we know it. She will know better when we stop.”

The sanctuary—or the idea of it, because the word felt delicate in their mouths—sat inland on the slopes where olive trees did the work of old men, watching and producing and insisting on their usefulness. The turnoff was foolish and then became a road with arrogant stones and then a track that belonged more to donkeys than to dented trucks. A boy with a balloon stood watching from a wall as if waiting for applause for simply existing so well in this heat. A goat declared its opinion of them in a voice that made Rima think of her landlord’s stamp and how the two were equal in power in many situations.

When the gate appeared, it didn’t at first. It was the absence of movement where fences began, the way boundaries make a silence around them to alert the attentive. A man with heat-swollen knuckles swung the gate back, his face giving away nothing except that he had learned to love animals and people in the precise ratio that kept him from breaking. He nodded at Noura, then let his eyes rest for a second on Rima as if acknowledging that strangers collected their own disasters and delivered them like gifts that were both welcome and not.

“Karim,” Noura said into the air and then into his hand when he offered it, and the gatekeeper’s mouth made a shape Rima recognized from men who had been asked for more than they had to give and refused to become bitter as payment. He led them to a low stone building whose interior had been scoured into cleanliness, the kind that looked like a promise kept one thousand times in small ways. A chain-link pen stood to the side like a mouth mid-sentence, and beyond it a field where shade was an argument that trees had nearly won.

They did not open the crate at once. Animals do not need your catharsis more than they need order, and Karim lifted a finger in the air to hush the urge to see her step into her new constraint. He tuned the room the way musicians tune an instrument no one will play. Water first, then quiet, then the low murmur of human intent bending itself to usefulness. Adel stood just inside the door and for the first time allowed his body to confess fatigue, which made Rima appreciate him as a creature rather than an instrument. Hadi took the coil of rope from the floor and tested its give, not because it would be used but because hands need a task when the heart is near the edge of a pond it has been told not to fall into.

“Later, we try the enclosure,” Karim said, finally letting language join them officially. “Today, we let her breathe a new square. Tomorrow, we move the sky.” His smile cut his face in a way that was tender and ugly at the same time, which is to say true. “You waited for this,” he added, and Rima felt seen in the way that made her grateful and angry, a combination that had fueled many of her jokes and too many of her mistakes.

When the locks slid, she stood at a distance she measured with the rules Noura had given her and the ones her body had learned in the last month. Mishmish stepped forward with the offended grace of a queen getting off a plane that had not landed on time. The scent of new dust slipped into the old dust like cousins meeting for the first time at a funeral. The animal took the light with her like furniture taken out of a room modifies the remaining shadow. She turned once, a half circle that made patterns blur, and then settled on a patch of concrete that felt, perhaps, like its own absence of catastrophe.

Karim moved without moving, the kind of stillness that is work. He kept everyone behind an invisible line he had drawn in his head years ago and could lay across a floor with precision. He held a hose in his hand not pointed at her, letting the notion of water populate the room before its reality arrived. He spoke under his breath to Mishmish and to the air and to the mistakes of men who had brought animals here in worse situations and demanded miracles out of polite rooms. Rima did not cry, because she did not want to see herself crying in this story at this point. She allowed her face to rearrange itself quietly, which is one of the few strengths she inherited from Salma without resenting the source.

“I will come back?” she asked Noura and then regretted the question because of the upward tilt of the last word. “If I can, I mean. If you say my face will not make her ask for a different room.”

“You can come,” Noura said. “You can also learn how to leave. Both are acts. We practice both.” It was not a comfort and it was not not a comfort. It was a sentence Rima recognized as having been written long before either of them spoke it.

They stood for a time that couldn’t decide what it was—long enough for Mishmish to close her eyes and open them again and close them once more, long enough for the sweat on their backs to confess itself through fabric, short enough that they kept thinking of the truck as still moving. The sounds here were different from the city, not quieter exactly but less busy with themselves. A donkey complained in an alto that made Rima smile despite herself. Somewhere a dog hit exactly three barks and then reconsidered the point. The wind admitted that it had been to the sea and come back with gossip that did not concern them.

Leila messaged that she had eaten half the dates she had packed for them and felt guilty and then better, a very Leila sequence. Maya sent a question mark and Rima answered it with the outline of a tiger drawn with too much wrist, which Maya would either berate her for or frame. Salma did not call. The empty space where her mother’s voice would be settled itself at the base of Rima’s spine and kept her upright in a way the truck had not.

Leaving the crate felt like leaving a church after lighting a candle. You exit into light you are not ready for, and you think about errands before you should and you half expect the sky to insist on solemnity and of course it does not. Karim shook Adel’s hand in a way that honored the driver’s part of the prayer. He put a hand briefly on Hadi’s shoulder and said something low that made Hadi nod, a single sharp thing that looked like agreement with himself. To Rima, he offered nothing except a long look that took in the thin newness of her and returned to her an older thing she might be able to wear.

On the way back, the road changed its order because roads are like that around here, but also because the vehicles moving on it had gathered other stories during the hours they were occupied elsewhere. The billboard now featured a different woman whose teeth promised a different future. A man with a ladder moved it from the shoulder to the bed of a pickup with a balletic seriousness that broke into laughter when the ladder kissed him on the ear. Hadi leaned his head out of the window and let the heat clap his cheeks in the way of an elder admonishing and blessing in the same gesture.

“You did it,” he said, quiet so it could be true without ceremony. “You tried to make a door and then you helped someone walk through it. It is less insane in the doing than in the saying.”

“I thought it would make me—” she began, and stopped before the word famous could humiliate them both. “I thought it would make me more like the person I want to be when I think about myself in the dark.”

“You are exactly as annoying as before,” Hadi said kindly, and she let herself laugh because both halves of the sentence had room for that. “Maybe there is less noise between your ears. Maybe not. We will see.”

When the second checkpoint appeared again in reverse it behaved like a different man who had borrowed the same body. They were waved through without fanfare because unpredictability had clocked out. The first did not look up from his phone. By the time Beirut’s shoulder rose to meet them, the air had grown thick with afternoon and the promise of generator breath. The Corniche was full of pairs and trios walking the length between memory and practicalities. The city had not changed while they were gone, which should have disappointed her and did not.

Back at the cinema, the iron door blinked at her new paint in the overstated light of four o’clock. The fan waited where she had left it, patient and old and obnoxiously correct.
