Rima stepped inside and the absence of the crate struck her like an extra sense she hadn’t named before. The room was emptier in the way a hand is emptier once you have taken off a ring you didn’t always like. She stood in the middle and let that hollowness ring against her ribs until it found the note it wanted to hold.

The first thing she did was pick up the hose and coil it with the care of putting a child’s arm into a sleeve. The second thing she did was sit on the plastic chair and put her feet where the square of pacing had darkened the concrete, a small sacrilege that felt like measuring her shoe against a footprint at a museum. The third thing she did was open her notebook and write three sentences about the way a truck sounds when it carries something that resembles consequence. The fourth thing she did was text Salma: She is in a place with trees, and then wait for her mother to not answer, because that too was a way of being answered.

Hadi peeled himself off the doorway and stretched his back, then announced that he was going to buy too much watermelon and that she had no choice but to help him eat it. When he left, the hallway coughed up a neighbor who wanted to tell Rima about the eggs she had found that morning with shells so thin it felt like breaking promises with her breakfast. Rima listened with governmental attention, nodding in the right places, and when the neighbor asked about “the matter”, Rima said something so bland it graduated into poetry. “We are practicing being less ridiculous,” she answered, and watched the relief move across the woman’s face like shade in a courtyard.

She slept a little on the couch with her mouth open, an unglamorous sleep she had been snobbish about once and now regarded as a gift. When she woke, her body had learned three new translations for the word tired and the heat had learned another way to be inside her. She went to her desk and wrote without aiming for herself, the way a person waters the part of a garden that doesn’t belong to her so she can look at it later and remember that the world makes things she didn’t plan. The first paragraph was about the morning, the second about the second soldier’s eyes, the third about the way money feels when it is wrapped in paperwork like a bad truth dressed as a good one.

At some either-or hour, the phone vibrated with Salma’s name and Rima did not pretend she might not pick up. Her mother’s voice wore a layer of fatigue that had been ironed flat by competency. “I bought soap,” she said without greeting, which was her greeting. “The curtains are so filthy I am embarrassed to hang them in any story you will write. Come tomorrow and we will make the kitchen smell like lemon and old television.”

“I will come,” Rima said, and was startled to hear herself sounding as if she believed she deserved a quiet job. “Bring me news about the woman who waters with the hose.”

“She watered too much,” Salma said with the satisfaction of someone whose predictions of folly had been validated. “Her basil is offended. It is still alive. You can be like the basil, habibti. Offended and alive.”

After they hung up, Rima went back to the cinema and stood in the doorway as the day divided itself into the two cities everyone always had to choose between: the one with electricity and the one without. She thought of Mishmish, of the rectangle of shade Karim had calibrated, of Hadi’s shoulders at rest when he finally let himself sit on the stoop with a wedge of watermelon and spit seeds with the joy of a boy who had been given permission to be vulgar. She let the thought of Maya’s deadline press against the front of her skull the way a pet presses a nose against a hand it might let bite. She did not try to make the next day come faster. For a woman always in love with the next paragraph, it felt like letting a wild and inappropriate animal put its head in her lap and keep it there while she breathed.

When night came, it did not perform. It slid in with the minor chords of generators and a cat’s yawn and the sigh of a city that had once again chosen to live despite having reasons to abstain. Rima took Abu Fadi’s fan back and he looked at the empty place where the crate used to be and said nothing about it, which in landlord was a compliment. He did tell her the plant in the hallway had made its decision and that death did not need to be discussed in public. She thanked him like he had given her something, because he had.

On her way back upstairs, she saw the boy with the messy hair sitting on the steps, his camera in his lap and his head leaned against the wall in that uncontrolled posture of someone who could nap even through artillery. He opened his eyes when he heard her and smiled, and for the first time since he had appeared in her doorway she liked him without needing to mother him or warn him off. “Did it work?” he asked, and when she nodded, he lifted the camera not to photograph her but to hold it to his own forehead like a cool cloth. “Good,” he said, and there was such clean belief in the two syllables that she wanted to give him a paragraph to keep in his pocket like a talisman.

“Go home,” she told him, and then sat with him for five minutes exactly, saying nothing, watching the staircase’s shadows with the precision of two people who had watched enough dramatic things to recognize the quiet ones that mattered more. He stood when she stood and they nodded at each other as if exchanging identifications. On the last step, she thought she heard the sea breathe, which was ridiculous and also correct. She went inside and closed the door gently so it would not forget it was a door and not a drum, and the city outside kept talking to itself in a language she had finally stopped pretending she did not speak.The curtains made a sound when they came off the rod that reminded Rima of a small animal surrendering, not loud enough to be tragic, just audible enough to register. Salma had stacked bowls of lemon halves like bright moons along the edge of the sink, and the radio on the counter insisted on giving recipe tips between traffic updates in a voice that had survived three wars without adjusting its tone. Soap foamed with a sting that made the pads of their fingers feel both punished and absolved. In her mother’s kitchen, even fatigue felt domesticated; it sat in the chair with the broken cane seat and agreed to participate in discussion in the proper order. They worked without performing it for each other, because work memorized between two people is its own dialect and requires no glossaries.

“You tie the knot the wrong way,” Salma said for the first time that morning, and it was a sentence that could have applied to the curtain rope or to a list of Rima’s romances. Rima smiled because she liked the way her mother made critique sound like heritage. The window pulled a stripe of heat over their forearms every time the breeze lied and pretended it would be relief, and the lemon made the air smell like somebody had tried to erase an old mistake with a citrus eraser. Salma’s hands moved with the fluid bossiness of a woman who had taught a sock to become a puppet because the child in front of her had demanded entertainment when money refused to participate.

“I’m writing the piece,” Rima announced, and the pronoun was the only piece of swagger she allowed herself in that kitchen. “Maya wants it with a spine. She says if my sentences do not have backs, readers will hang their coats on them anyway and complain when the coats fall.”

“Listen to the woman who wears crisp shirts,” Salma replied, because style was not separate from authority in her book. She turned the curtain so that the clean side accused the dirty side, and the contrast embarrassed them both a little. “Write, but don’t leave words like snakes under people’s beds. We already have mice.”

Rima thought of the mice in the back room of the cinema, the way they had adjusted their routes around a crate that smelled like wilderness. She thought of Karim’s hands that had held rope and hose with equal competence, and of Mishmish stepping into a rectangle of new air with a queen’s skepticism. She told her mother only the parts that could be told without making the room tilt—the road, the second soldier’s eyes, the bit of road where the sea decided to be serious. Salma listened with the concentration she reserved for recipes that did not belong to her lineage and therefore required extra humility. When the curtains hung again, wet and temporarily dignified, they were heavy as a promise kept for now.

The piece grew around the sentence Maya had bossed her into keeping like a woman makes soup around a bone she refuses to toss. Rima wrote in the morning because her body had conceded that resistance at eleven felt like silliness and at seven felt like a principle. She wrote about the heat as if it were an uncle with a loud laugh who visited every year with the same jokes, and about paperwork like a sea monster that occasionally let a boat pass when it was in love. She described the truck’s grammar without showing off, and the men who decided whether she could pass as if they had invented ambivalence and wanted credit for it. She wrote about her fingers wanting to slide between bar and fur and the way adults teach themselves to stand back when they want to step forward, and she kept that paragraph even though she feared it made her look sentimental in a way she had mocked in other people.

Maya sent back notes that were half scalpel, half flirtation. She deleted three metaphors because they were doing the same work with worse clothes, and she circled a line about sponsorship with a pencil that must have been expensive because even the mark felt rich. Keep this. Bury it where no one expects to find it and then let it walk out on its own legs. Rima found herself obeying with a pleasure that at nineteen would have offended her, because she had confused obedience with surrender and had not learned yet the difference between good editors and dictators. They met once at a café where the spoons were cold on purpose and where the barista had revolutionary forearms. Maya took the seat facing the door and glanced at Rima’s mouth when she laughed as if checking for a small lie. “You have a dangerous relationship with your endings,” she said, and Rima answered that she had worse relationships with other things, so she would take that as progress.

Hadi came to her apartment the day before his third session with Ghida and sat on the floor with his back against the couch because the fan was honest there. He wore a T-shirt with a logo that had meant something once and had washed itself into anonymity. From his pocket he produced a slip of paper that had been folded and refolded into a piece of origami that did not exist. He passed it to her without ceremony and chewed the side of his thumb not because he was nervous but because he had never learned a better habit.

“I told a man no,” he said while she unfolded. “At the ninth, the one who throws his club as if gravity were flirting with him. He told me to clean his ball with my shirt because the towel was ‘tired’, and I told him I was not an extension of his laundry. He laughed and tried to make it a joke, and I did not let him have it. He called me difficult. I told him that difficulty is movement when you are used to a wheelchair.”

On the paper, in his precise letters that somehow managed to look like someone apologizing to a line, he had written a sentence that carried its own weight correctly. I do not have to be agreeable to be good. Rima read it twice and then a third time in the same way she had read the graffiti on the iron door, and this time what dripped was not accusation but relief. She told him that if he wrote twenty more sentences like this he would have a stack a man could sit on. He looked at her with the wide open face he hated and loved when it took over and then ruined it by sticking his tongue out, which was a relief to both of them because earnestness should be interrupted by ridiculousness at least once an hour in this heat.

Noura called with the tone of someone requesting a favor while also delivering good news and asked if Rima wanted to come up to the sanctuary on a day that would be unwise to drive but perfect for a small ceremony. “The sky is wrong,” she said. “But Karim says the animal is ready to feel grass that remembers bigger feet. If you come, you do not own the moment. You are invited to borrow it. Wear shoes that will forgive rocks.” Rima agreed and then put down the phone and stood still for a full minute because sometimes stillness was a superstition and sometimes it was a way to let the news move through without getting stuck.

The sanctuary smelled different when the heat stepped back temporarily and let the earth breathe. Trees made shade that wasn’t an apology but a plan, and the insects made a choir so industrious it sounded like a factory run by gossip. Karim nodded once at her from under a hat that had once been a better hat and motioned toward a gate at the far end of the pen where Mishmish had learned the new square, the chain-link singing quietly the constant high note it kept whether or not anyone listened. The small procession was absurd and precise: Noura with a clipboard as if paper could domesticate fate, Karim with a length of rope on his shoulder he would not use, two volunteers whose eyes had learned the trick of being present without becoming a mirror, and Rima with a watermelon under her arm because Hadi had given it to her with a grin and a knife and the idea that rituals could be invented for animals who did not need them.

They opened two doors that had agreed to behave like one, and then they opened the idea of the sky. Mishmish considered it the way a woman considers a dress she has always admired on other bodies. She stepped onto the shade first, which was sensible, and then the sun, which was not naïveté but an experiment. Her paws adjusted the way small boats adjust when moved to bigger water, and her breath changed and changed back in a rhythm that told Karim it was fine and told Rima that whatever gratitude she wanted from this creature would be a human thing she would have to give herself. The animal bent her head to the grass the way a queen lowers her face to a bouquet from an obedient city and then, in a gesture that made Karim exhale a laugh he had not authorized, she rolled onto her side once with both dignity and abandon. The fence when struck by sunlight made a careless lace all over the square of her and then stopped making metaphors because it was a fence and had no right.

There were other animals at the edges—eyes that had learned to accept squares in exchange for not being eaten, ears that had learned the privacy of listening when men used the wrong voices around them. Rima did not ask their names because she had begun to respect the inefficiency of not knowing things. Noura signed three lines on a form that appeared to be the same form as yesterday and yet was not, and whispered to Karim about a hyena that had grown good at refusing medical interventions and a monkey that had fallen in love with a broom. “Let her smell you,” Karim told Rima when they had stood enough in their corner to be polite, and Rima reached her hand no farther than the air that remembered her. Mishmish glanced, blinked once, and returned to her grass. It was exactly the right amount of affection in a story that had remembered not to be hers.

The piece went online on a Thursday night that felt like Tuesday because calendar arithmetic had stopped working weeks ago. Maya had given it a title that Rima would have never given anything she wrote because it behaved itself and got to the point without wearing jewelry. People read it with the greedy speed of boredom given food, and then they read it slower, and then they sent it to their mothers and to their enemies. The line about lipstick and hunger lodged in the city’s mouth the way a piece of pita gets stuck against the back molar and cannot be dislodged by tongue alone, and the paragraph where Rima confessed to wanting to be considered worthy of a story brought her inbox both praise and knives.

A woman wrote to say that she had hated Rima for two days for being exactly the kind of writer who thought her feelings should be allowed to drive, and then she had forgiven her because of the sentence about ice that reminded her of her father’s hands. A man wrote to tell her he had taken photographs of bears in Syria and had never told anyone because the bears’ eyes had made him stop believing in light, and he had cried in his bathroom not because of her but because chemicals in the traffic fumes had made him sentimental. An uncle wrote to say that the word sanctuary irritated him, and a girl wrote to ask if the tiger’s stripes were really as symmetrical as they looked in cartoons. Noura called to say that three people had inquired about donating without their names being written anywhere and that even if two were lying this was a miracle and a half. Maya sent an emoji she would never admit to owning and a message that said, now do not enjoy your little fame in a way that breaks the piece’s back.

Leila arrived the next day with a haircut that had committed to its own unevenness and a story about her boss that required a chair because indignation should be told from a higher place. She had ordered a protest T-shirt online and it had arrived with the slogan misspelled by one letter, and somehow that error had described the whole country more perfectly than anything else had that morning. She wanted to quit, and then she wanted to burn the office down, and then she wanted to ask her mother if she could move home and become the version of herself who thought she would be a teacher because chalk had looked like magic. Rima told her to quit for fifteen minutes every day as practice and to stay for the other twenty-three hours and forty-five minutes as an experiment. They sat on the floor with watermelon and spat seeds into a bowl until the bowl resembled a small conspiracy.

Abu Fadi caught her on the stairs with a look on his face that was arguing with joy about whether it was appropriate to appear in public. He had read the piece because his nephew had sent it with too many exclamation marks and he had said he did not like exclamation marks because they were unhygienic. “You did not embarrass our building,” he informed her, which was his native dialect for congratulations. He told her the plant in the corridor had finally chosen dignity and had been replaced by a snake plant that would not dare die in this heat because it did not have the necessary imagination. When she thanked him for the fan again, he waved away gratitude as if it were a fruit fly and asked if the fan had stopped making that high whining noise that meant its bearing needed oil. She was, in that moment, overwhelmed by the tenderness of men who think they are talking about machines when they are talking about love.

The boy with the older camera found her outside the bakery, waited until she had finished being told about the oven’s mood by the baker, and then showed her his one photo. He had kept his promise. He had taken it from the threshold so that bars and light and the idea of an animal had been invited to share the frame without any one of them feeling used. It was better than proof. It was the sort of photograph that made you think of windows. “Caption it with one sentence you can’t take back,” she told him when he asked what he should do with it. He nodded like a person accepting medicine from a spoon and promised to try. He asked her then if writing felt like this all the time, like balancing a bowl of water and laughing because you were not allowed to spill. It felt nothing like that, she told him. It felt worse and better and sometimes like dry bread.

On the Corniche, twilight made men into silhouettes that looked taller and women into punctuation marks placed carefully in the sentence of the day. The sea breathed truths it refused to share with anyone who asked for them by name. Rima walked to the bench under the tree that had always understood hair and took from her bag a notebook and a pen that worked only if held at the correct angle, which was to say stubbornly. She had promised herself a page that was not about tigers or laws or the heat’s biography. She wrote about a boy she had once loved for three months and then pretended not to know because he had called her his mountain and she had realized she wanted to be river. She wrote about the woman who watered her basil too much because of fear and then corrected herself, watering less because she had converted fear into discipline, which is one of the few miracles available to civilians. She wrote four sentences that no one would ever read and felt the fan of Abu Fadi’s apartment turning somewhere above like proof that small machines can make decisions in your favor when you are not paying attention.

Ghida called her because Hadi had given her number and asked if she wanted to sit for an hour in a room where the chairs made no sounds and the curtains had been chosen by someone who knew what you were doing with your eyes when you lied. Rima told herself she was going to see what Hadi talked about, not because she needed anything. She sat on a couch that did not claim to be anything else and listened to a woman ask questions that were knives with soft handles, and she surprised herself by not performing. The hour stretched and contracted and then finished. She did not cry. She did not become new. She agreed to come again because agreeing to come again was the least dramatic way to tell herself she had noticed something.

At the club, a week later, she stood over a ball and did not ask it to give her anything except its flight. Hadi watched with his arms crossed in an arrangement that looked casual and was not. “Swing like you have already written the paragraph,” he coached, which was either ridiculous or the only useful thing anyone had ever said to her about sports. She swung and found, to her irritation and delight, that the ball obeyed an agreement she had not made consciously. The man with the towel around his neck watched and kept his mouth shut because the day was hot and he had used his jokes elsewhere. Hadi did his small owlish nod that meant he was proud and would deny it later if it made the air sticky.

The city did what it always did with other people’s business: it took it and made it taste like the thing you already had in your mouth. The piece spawned counterpieces and endorsements and a sticker on a lamppost that made Rima laugh because it was a cartoon of a tiger wearing a keffiyeh and sunglasses and the word APRICOT underneath in a font that would embarrass a child. Someone spray-painted THANK YOU on the iron door and then someone else added FOR WHAT? and then a third person drew a flower with six petals that looked like it had been painted by a woman on a phone call that had lasted too long. She bought a paintbrush and did nothing because the door had become a conversation and not participating in a conversation is one form of speech.

Noura sent a video ignorant of the concept of resolution in which Mishmish stood with her head up in a light that did her stripes a favor and then lowered it to push her cheek against the wire as if the world were a thing that could be nudged into a more favorable angle. Karim wrote two words under the video that were not a caption so much as a verdict: She remembers. Rima watched the video with the particular jealousy one feels for animals who know where they are without having to name it, and then she walked home and made eggs and burned the first one and laughed alone in her kitchen because even breakfast half the time is betrayal and romance.

There was a protest on a Saturday that drew the city into one place briefly like a magnet makes a shape out of filings. Rima went because staying home is also a political act and she had done too many of those this year already. The signs were better than two years ago because everyone had learned to spell in anger and to not rhyme when rhyme made things silly. A man sprayed water in an arc that made strangers bless him for being generous in public, and women stood with their backs to the cameras so that their faces would not be borrowed for arguments they did not want to join. Rima walked beside Leila and did not talk because chanting felt like karaoke and she had never liked karaoke, but she liked the way the chant moved through other people’s ribcages and made them taller for an hour. When the line dissolved into smaller lines and then into individuals moving toward hummus, she felt for a moment the particular sadness of people who know they will go home to the same walls and the same bills and the same threshold and that the world changes so slowly it sometimes looks like a statue.

Maya asked her to sit on a panel about stories and animals and the way cities digest both without chewing, and Rima almost said yes because a chair with a microphone is a love language she has been trying to divorce for years. She said no and then walked to the room anyway and stood in the back like a teenager and listened to people say useful and useless things in equal measure. She went home and wrote about washing curtains instead, and when Maya read the paragraph about lemon and apology and the dignity of rod and fabric, she wrote back a one-word email that made Rima tear up because it was exactly the praise she had always wanted. Finally.

Hadi told her he wanted to stop caddying soon and to try to be the person he had imagined out loud as a joke, the one who walked with people and named holes before ankles found them. He had two clients who were both women who liked to pay for things up front and a boy who had refused money and brought him, instead, three mangos and a book of poems with half the pages uncut. He asked Rima to help him write a page that explained what he did to people who did not believe in anything except receipts. She agreed to sit and ask him questions until he had answers that wanted to be written. They did that work at a table in a café with chairs that were slightly too low for the table, which made the whole business feel like humility. His sentences arrived reluctantly and then, when they felt safe, came fast, like stray cats deciding the hand being offered was not a trick.

The first rain in September arrived with the arrogance of a guest who had been late on purpose. People stood at their windows pretending to find fault with it so they could explain later why they had not invited it in. The drops were enormous and spaced wide as if a sky had to remember how to do this work after too many months of fire. The smell of dust being made into mud slipped under doors and into shirts and bent the shoulders of men who had forgotten to call their sisters. Rima walked to the cinema for the pleasure of watching water make the floor dark and round, and found the boy with the older camera standing under the awning wearing his father’s jacket. He told her he had written his sentence and she asked him to read it aloud because some phrases exist only in mouths. He cleared his throat and looked at the photograph and said, softly and a little too fast, I did not know a cage could teach me the size of my own hands. She told him to slow down and say it again and he did and the rain approved with a louder spell of itself.

Salma came with plastic bags tied like balloons and a vegetable stew that had not asked to be anything other than what it was. She sat on the couch and called the fan an old man for falling asleep mid-conversation. She told Rima that the woman with the hose had become famous in the building for killing thrips by flicking them with a nail she refused to cut, and that neighbors had begun to ask her for basil as if she were a bank. They watched a drama on television in which a sister betrayed a sister for a man who owned a restaurant, and they argued in a low voice about whether it was believable that any woman would abandon a sister for the owner of a restaurant that served its hummus with pink peppercorns. When the episode ended on a cliff and the commercials arrived with their plastic gusto, Salma turned to her daughter and said, as if passing salt at dinner, “Enough with animals for a while. Write about something stupid like laundry. We need that stupid. It is our vitamin.”

She went back up north once more in that season because the roads permitted it and because Karim had said the animal had learned a path around the enclosure that was hers and he wanted Rima to see it once and then stop coming for a while. She stood at the fence with her fingers flat against the air and watched Mishmish trace a map that had been drawn in her muscles, a loop that looked complicated and was not. Birds made announcements without translating themselves for humans, and an olive tree released a single leaf with the solemnity of a man signing a treaty. Karim told her that the animal had scratched herself on the rough trunk of a tree and had not bled, and that he had been relieved in a way he could not explain to anyone who had not waited all afternoon for an animal not to bleed. He told her that one of the volunteers had cried because she had looked into Mishmish’s eyes and seen patience and forgiven herself for none, and he had told the volunteer to stop using animals as mirrors and to buy a plant.

On the way back, traffic at the second checkpoint held them like a sentence refuses to end when you are tired. The man with the mustache was not there; a new boy had taken his stool and was trying to learn the moral weather. Noura, on the phone with someone whose voice was all vowels and deadlines, waved and got a wave back and Rima watched a village’s worth of power exchange itself in two small gestures and a flick of a wrist. She was, for a moment, overcome with a love for predictability so intense it made her think of extinguishers mounted on walls, and then someone cut across two lanes and nearly removed their side mirror and she remembered where she lived and smiled at the road even though it could not see her.

At night, she wrote a paragraph about hands. She wrote about her father’s and Karim’s and Hadi’s and the boy with the camera’s and Abu Fadi’s and her own when they gripped a rope or a pen or an orange thrown as a golf ball or a soaked curtain being wrung out in a kitchen that had cataloged more disasters than a newspaper. She wrote that hands have their own handwriting and that if you place your palm on a table you will hear a story if you are patient and impolite. She wrote that letting go is a verb you learn with wrists first, not heart. She kept that paragraph not because it was good but because it was honest enough to be allowed in the room with her other better paragraphs without staring at them too long.

In bed she practiced not thinking about anything that had claws. She practiced not rehearsing arguments she would never have with strangers under online articles. She practiced wanting small things and then wanting nothing. She told herself out loud that she could be the kind of person who brought a tiger to the city and then took her out of it and still be allowed to have other sentences. Sleep came like a woman who had been kept waiting and decided to forgive her anyway for the sake of the next day, and the generator sang its minor key and then took a breath and held it, which in this city was a kind of lullaby.The morning after the rain, the city wore its damp like a new scarf it was not sure how to arrange, and Rima woke into a light that had sharpened edges and polite shadows. The window screens exhaled a fine cool and the apartment had the smell she privately called the smell of beginning again: metal a little cleaned by weather, lemons somewhere insisting on their usefulness, dust deciding to behave. She boiled water on the stove because the generator had chosen to rehearse indifference, and the kettle’s thin scream braided with the radio from Salma’s kitchen through the wall so that for a moment the two rooms decided to be one. She thought about the piece and its small ripples and about Mishmish tracing her uncomplicated path around an enclosure, and she let the fact that there was nothing dramatic to do today settle over her shoulders like a shawl she had learned to like by wearing it often.

She took the bus out of superstition rather than need, because buses were a way of asking a city to tell you what it thought of you without resorting to surveys. Men clung to the inside of the door as if it were a family tradition and a boy balanced a tray of coffees for a distance that felt like a miracle performed for free, and when they lurched towards the ring road a woman in blue sandals began to tell a stranger the exact recipe for keeping basil arrogant. Rima listened with the greed she reserved for other people’s recipes and imagined the basil on her neighbor’s balcony raising an eyebrow at the advice, then turned her attention to a billboard in which a woman with a powdered face sold a future that included better skin and, somehow, a passport. She wanted to be irritated and found instead that she was fond of the way the driver’s rosary clicked against the plastic of the dashboard, a little percussion instrument insisting on its right to be part of the orchestra of this day.

Maya had asked for a proposal that did not apologize for being a book, and Rima sat in a café with tables that had been repainted so many times the wood was an anecdote under coats of ambition and looked at a blank document titled In Care Of. She wrote an opening paragraph and deleted it because it was writing like a person pretending to be someone who had written a first draft before, and then she wrote another that was worse and kept it out of spite. She watched the barista wipe the counter in circles that got bigger when the conversation with a friend got more interesting and felt a sudden panic that she was trying to invent a ladder to a roof she was not sure she wanted to be on. She drank her coffee, which did not try to be metaphorical, and began again with a sentence about the way time bends around acts of attention, and this time she did not delete it, not because it was good but because it pointed in a direction that made her body lean.

She met Hadi in the late afternoon under the jacaranda that had decided to drop purple without consulting anyone’s schedule, and his face had a shine she recognized from boys who had learned to say no without apologizing for the electricity that followed. He told her he had two clients who had cried and one who had laughed and one who had simply looked at the floor and asked if he could be rude for an hour without consequence, and that he had stood the whole time because sitting would have made him patient and he wanted to be something else. He confessed that he had written an invoice and then rewritten it three times because the numbers looked like confessions he was not ready to make, and she told him to pick a number he would be embarrassed to say aloud and then divide it by two and then add a little for the future. They had the kind of argument that friends who trust each other have about money, which always ends with the air between them slightly cleaned and the sense that if they were in fact poor they were poor together in a way that made it less humiliating.

The inspector returned to the cinema at a time of day chosen to make statements feel bigger, his mustache trimmed down into a more aerodynamic opinion and a new folder under his arm that had learned to perform consequence. He stepped inside and stood in the square where the crate had lived as if waiting to be haunted, and when he realized the ghost would not show itself, he clicked his pen twice and looked at Rima the way teachers look at students who insist on being difficult on Fridays. He had brought forms after all, and he laid them on the plastic table like a deck of cards while informing her in a tone that attempted fatherhood that fines were possible, that permission had not been granted in advance, that the city wanted to be consulted even when it had no plan to help. Rima listened until listening became an act of politeness rather than civic duty, and then she said yes in the correct places and said mm in the places where agreement would be a lie pretended in the service of peace, and when he asked her what had been inside she told him the truth in the past tense and watched it become small immediately in his expression.

The graffiti reappeared in a different hand, one that wrote letters like ladders without rungs so that phrases looked like they had given up halfway to escape, and this time it read: TAKE YOUR SHOW ELSEWHERE. Rima stood and read it as if it were advice from a relative with an agenda and then went to buy paint and did not paint it because she did not want to erase the record of a city talking to itself in bad moods. Leila came with a paper bag of sesame biscuits and announced that she had quit her job for forty-five minutes and then taken it back and that she was experimenting with freedom in small doses like a person who has been fasting and understands that gluttony will make her sick. They sat on the threshold and ate and talked about leaving and staying and about another person they knew who had moved to Berlin and now pretended it was impossible to find parsley, and for a moment both of them were loyal to the idea of another place. The biscuits left a dust that felt like a blessing on their fingers, and a boy on a bicycle coasted past so beautifully upright they both applauded in their heads.

Salma’s neighbor began to lose names at the edges, the kind of forgetting that makes everyone suddenly experts at tenderness and at denial, and Rima found herself sitting in the woman’s living room while Salma argued with a cousin on the phone about the difference between help and interference. The neighbor offered Rima a plate of pistachios and then forgot she had done so and then offered again, and the B-movie on the television looped a scene in which a man promised a woman he would become a better version of himself after the next commercial break. Rima thought about the way memory could be a country with borders that changed every night without announcing anything to the neighbors and wondered how many versions of her father remained in Salma’s mind and which one was allowed to cook in the kitchen of their shared nostalgia. When they left, Salma kissed the neighbor’s forehead and called her by her name because names were the last flags you surrender, and on the staircase she said aloud to no one in particular that the city should charge tax on worry because otherwise it had no revenue stream that made moral sense.

Up at the sanctuary, Karim began to trust her a little in the specific way that men who live with animals trust women who do not insist on being looked at while they are being useful, and he let her carry buckets without monitoring the angle of her elbows. The goats had learned to ignore new humans unless those humans tried to be goats, and the monkeys had learned a routine of mischief that involved the theft of exactly one glove every afternoon as a demonstration of their commitment to humor. Mishmish was larger than she had been in Rima’s mind, which made Rima think of how certain friendships improve when they are allowed to grow beyond the size of the story that started them, and when the animal lay in a patch of sun she did it with the authority of a creature that has decided to impress nobody. Karim spoke with his hand on a fencepost as if that made the words less arrogant coming out, and he told her that an animal does not become a lesson unless you insist on it, and that the best days are the days when nothing is learned and everything is done.

Noura had an argument with a ministry that pretended to be a person in a suit and ended the phone call with a sentence that could have been used as a knife if she had wanted to cut anything, and then she laughed with her whole face in a way that made Rima want to like all bureaucrats who did not deserve it. The road back down from the sanctuary had softened with the rain and insisted on making the truck perform intimacy with the earth, and a boy carrying a basket of figs that were more bruise than fruit offered them one each with the generosity of a person who had decided to be rich when he had a handful of sweetness. They drove with the windows down so they could carry the smell of the hillside into the city and smear it across the concrete like a charm that would not work, and when they passed the billboard with the new watch promising to stop time Rima yelled at it, gently, to mind its business. The sea took their voices and did not bother to give them back, which felt like relief.

Hadi asked her to attend one of his group sessions because he had discovered that when men sat in a circle they either said nothing or everything and he needed a woman who could be a chair that asked questions without being sat on. She sat with four men who had learned their own names in different countries and listened to a man who had once been called a genius in a room with glass walls confess that he had begun to hate his own adjectives, and to another who admitted that he sometimes wandered the supermarket for the comfort of fluorescent certainty. Hadi kept time without looking at his watch because he had learned the length of other people’s courage in minutes, and when one of the men said that he was tired of his jokes not being funny anymore Rima said gently that perhaps they had done their work and could be put to bed. The hour stretched and then snapped back, and as they stood to leave she watched one of them fold his anger into a pocket like a handkerchief he might need later and decided she liked this quiet work even though it made her skin feel too thin for a while.

The landlord’s sister moved in on the third floor and rearranged the hallway with rugs that smelled like storage, and her boy left sneaker marks on the staircase in patterns that suggested dance and impatience. She greeted Rima as if they had once shared a table at a funeral and asked immediately what exactly it was Rima did for a living and whether it made steady money, and when Rima said writer the woman made the face people make when told about a medical condition they do not believe is real. Abu Fadi watched from his doorway with an expression that combined pride and dread and later told Rima in the tone of a man confessing a small sin that his sister had been sent back to him by a husband who needed space, and that she would bring many plants and many rules and that everyone should prepare themselves. He then handed Rima a small bag of nails and asked her to fix the hinge to a cupboard because the carpenter had become allergic to his own promises and needed to be punished by being replaced with neighbors.

She and Leila went swimming in Batroun one evening because their bodies demanded salt like a song and the road had given them an hour in which to pretend they were women who could decide such things. The sea held them without asking for names and handed them back to the shore gently, and they lay on their towels with wet hair like children after a long day of pretending to be dragons. They talked about leaving again and about staying again and about how staying could be a plan and not a failure if you dressed it right, and when the sky put on its apricot they said the word Mishmish at the same time and then did not talk for a whole minute, which for them was a rare and expensive silence. A group of teenagers practiced sorrow by kicking a ball and missing on purpose so they could groan and then laugh, and Leila told Rima that she had made a list of ten things that would make her life 7 percent better and that she was on number three, which was buying a trash can she did not despise.

The proposal grew in layers like a cake for a person who despises icing, and Rima began to enjoy the feeling of building something that did not need to be shared yet, which she realized was a new pleasure for her in this century of public drafts. She wrote about the difference between sponsorship and care with fewer metaphors and more nouns, and she placed the chapter about Mishmish not at the beginning like a surprise she needed to spoil for herself but closer to the middle, where the weight could be carried by other stories that had none of the glamour of teeth. She investigated her father with restraint and decided that when she wrote about him she would put the best version of him in the kitchen and the worst on the balcony, which felt fair because balconies had always been where her family confessed its foolishness to the open air. When she sent ten pages to Maya, she cried in the bathroom before reading the notes not because she expected cruelty but because kindness had begun to be a thing that frightened her when it arrived on time.

Ghida asked about her sleep and Rima lied to see if she would be caught and then laughed at herself because lying to a woman you pay to hear you tell the truth felt like buying fruit and complaining about sweetness. The room where they sat had a plant that looked like it had been rescued from someone who overwatered it, and Rima stared at its leaves while she tried to describe what it meant to be watched by a city and also to be ignored by it, and how both could be a kind of hunger with different symptoms. Ghida said she was not interested in sentences that sounded like awards and asked her what she had wanted to do a week ago but had not, and Rima said that she had wanted to take the bus to her father’s grave and talk to the grass and had not because she had been embarrassed of her own theater. Ghida asked what was theatrical about talking to grass when grass minded its own business as a rule, and Rima admitted that she was not embarrassed for the grass but for the part of her that would try to narrate the meeting as if she were a magazine.

There was a small fire in a building down the street that was extinguished by neighbors with buckets and one man with a hose who did not turn the water off at the tap afterwards, and the result was a river down the stairs that carried cigarette butts and one slipper to the sidewalk where it laid them out like evidence. Rima watched from her window with the fascinated helplessness of a person who had not been chosen by crisis and felt the cheapness of that relief, and she went down to help carry a couch after the smoke had decided it had made its point. An old woman whose voice had never learned to be quiet thanked everyone loudly and declared the fire a cousin to all the other problems, and then asked if anyone had a fan to lend because her room had become the inside of a boiled potato. The street organized itself the way certain families do when death is visiting someone else and decided who would cook and who would clean and who would be allowed to sit with the woman and talk about God without pointing too directly at Him.

A letter arrived in the mail three weeks late and looked like it had fought a small war with a puddle and lost, and inside it was a note from the cousin of the owner of the old cinema asking in a tone of injured magnanimity whether she would be willing to pay a little more for the space now that it had acquired fame. The cousin had included a smiling photograph of himself holding a plate of grilled fish as if to prove that he was a man with appetites and not just a signature, and Rima took the letter to Abu Fadi like a child taking a misbehaving pet to a neighbor who had a way with animals. The landlord read it with the full attention of his eyebrows and then said he would handle it in a way that made Rima briefly love hierarchy, and he called the cousin and told him that if he had wanted more money he should have raised the rent before allowing his building to become a saint. When he hung up, he told Rima that he had saved her three meetings and two insults and that she owed him a tray of knafeh, and for once she did not argue with the economy of that exchange.

Hadi’s father appeared one evening with a plastic bag full of oranges that had been discouraged by their tree and asked if the building had a view of the harbor from a window he could stand at for a minute. He had a voice like cardboard softened by rain and eyes that had chosen to forgive more than they should have, and he stood at the window and watched nothing in particular and said only, it looks the same as twelve years ago and then it looks different, which is how time behaves when it wants to show off. He sat and drank tea with too much sugar and told her that Hadi had been the kind of boy who picked up nails from the road as if the road needed to be protected from itself, and that he was glad his son had found a way to ask men for money by giving them something that was not a lie. Before he left, he pressed a coin into her palm as if she were a child, and she put it in the bowl where she kept lost screws and spare buttons and the gold tooth of a story she had never written.

Autumn entered like a woman who has always had a key even if nobody remembered giving it to her, and the air did that trick of moving across skin as if it were reading. The city adjusted its noises downward by a half-step and soups began to be spoken of with more respect and shirts decided to be sleeves again. Rima found that her nights were less aggressive and that sleep visited without needing to be negotiated with like a poorly behaved guest, and she began to dream in longer sentences that did not require her to wake and write them down to be believed later. She went to the club twice in a week and did not apologize to herself, and she stood over a ball and swung without demanding any lesson from it, and when it landed where it should she felt the particular satisfaction of being competent at something that did not matter beyond the minutes in which it was being done.

The panel she had refused happened without her and then happened with her when Maya, who knew her better than she would admit, texted to say that one of the speakers had misunderstood the difference between metaphor and fact and could she please come and be impolite in an educated way. She stood on stage in shoes that did not pinch and said what she had promised herself she would say if ever given a microphone again, which was that animals were not reputations and that stories could be useful if they were built to be used rather than admired. A man asked a question that was really a speech and she answered with a question that was really a refusal, and the audience murmured the way audiences do when they are grateful to be watching someone else argue about a thing they feel strongly about. Afterward, a woman with a notebook asked her if she was afraid and Rima said yes in the voice of a person ordering bread, and the woman wrote the yes down as if it had been a more complicated word.

The boy with the camera brought her a copy of his photo printed on cheap paper that made the blacks into slowly surrendering grays, and he told her he had written his sentence on the back and then decided not to because he wanted the picture to be a place where people could be honest without being told what to think. He had been offered a small job at a wedding where the groom wanted to look surprised at being loved and the bride wanted to look like a person who had invented forgiveness, and he had said yes because money had become a muscle he wanted to train. He asked her how to invoice and she gave him Hadi’s sentence and told him to double it because weddings are expensive. He laughed in the untidy way of boys who have not learned to hide delight, and then he asked if the tiger remembered her and she said that what mattered was that the tiger remembered trees.

One evening near the end of the month, Salma called with the particular structure of breath that told Rima she had been about to say something else and changed her mind, and she asked if Rima would come to watch a television serial with her because she had realized she did not want to be alone when the sister betrayed the sister again. Rima went with bread and an onion and a cheap bottle of red that had won prizes in a week when prizes were being generous, and they sat shoulder to shoulder on the couch and argued in whispers about the motives of people who did not exist. During the commercial breaks, Salma told stories about her own sister that she had not told before because they had been stored in a drawer marked too big, and Rima realized with the gentle shock that sometimes accompanied her mother’s sentences that grief had made her mother kinder in a way no lecture could have taught. When she left, Salma pressed a bag of thyme into her hand and told her to eat stupidly in the morning and to try not to educate every hunger before satisfying it.

Mishmish appeared in her dreams sometimes now only as a temperature, a square of sun that moved over a floor and a sound of breath that straightened Rima’s back even when she was not aware of slouching. In one dream, the tiger lay under an olive tree and the tree told her a joke about men who insist on holding umbrellas for you in rain that is not falling, and Rima laughed in her sleep and woke with her mouth open and her throat unafraid. She began to learn the names of the volunteers not because names were important for their own sake but because she liked the way men and women said their names when asked by a person who planned to remember, and she liked the way Karim said good when a bucket landed where it should and bad when it did not and nothing at all when the moment needed quiet. She tired of talking about the piece and learned to redirect the conversation toward the weather and the price of parsley and the rumor of a storm like a woman practiced in a polite martial art.

There were small humiliations and small glories and an afternoon when she found a note in her mailbox that said simply THANK YOU in a hand that was learning to grow up and a morning when she went to the pharmacy and was corrected by a girl ten years younger than her for mispronouncing the name of a cream. There was a day when the electricity did not come back when it said it would and she read by a window with her knees cold and there was a day when her upstairs neighbor practiced the oud for two hours and she forgave him for every missed note because the attempt filled a hole in the air that had been bothering her. There was a night when she took the long way home because there is a time in every life when one must take a street one has been avoiding and nothing happened and later she congratulated herself for swimming without water. She practiced wanting less attention and more endurance, which in her mouth felt like a reasonable prayer.

The city sent her a notice that she had been assigned a number for something she did not understand and she went to a building with chairs that had known the weight of five hundred kinds of impatience, and she waited with people who were both more important and less in a hierarchy that had nothing to do with the good. A woman with a child asleep on her lap told her a joke about stamps and they laughed as if stamps could hear and be shamed into good behavior, and when her number arrived on the screen in a red that demanded performance she walked to the window and was told that the system was down as if the system were a horse that had decided to sit. She went home and wrote a page about systems and horses and decided to cut it later, and then did not cut it because it lent a paragraph the spine that it had been pretending to grow.

On a Sunday that smelled like old bread being turned into something better, she took the bus to the edge of the city and walked the last kilometer along a road that held the ruins of cinemas and the new birth of small restaurants with chairs that would break within a year. She entered a building that had been a school before it was a clinic and listened to a woman explain how to volunteer with children who had learned to be louder than their parents to get noticed, and she wrote her name on a paper and felt the thrill of committing to a thing that might be boring. The woman smiled in a way that suggested relief that someone still believed paperwork could transform time into service, and handed her a schedule that made sense to her mouth. On the bus back she sat next to a boy eating chips with diligence and a man reading a book as if it had betrayed him and she rested her head against the window and let the city find its way back into her bones as if there had ever been a time it had not lived there.

At night, the generator hit its middle C and held it as if trying to calm a child, and she wrote a paragraph about care that did not attempt to be pretty and could therefore be trusted. She wrote about the small ways people make each other less lonely in this place without turning it into a parade, and she wrote about the ugliness that sometimes arrives when people decide to be necessary. She wrote about holding and releasing, about doorways and thresholds and rituals that do not ask permission from any flag, and she wrote down the sentence Salma had thrown across the kitchen like a braid: be offended and alive. She slept with the window open and let the city’s breath lift the edge of her curtain, and when the dawn’s first scooter cut through the street she was grateful like a woman who had survived a test she had not studied for and decided to forgive herself for the questions she had answered poorly.The heat retreated for a week as if it had remembered an appointment elsewhere, and in the pause the city revealed small things that July had kept hidden under its sweaty palm. The mountains began to admit out loud that they were green under the dust, and the sea had the uncomplicated confidence of a dog off its leash. Rima walked differently when the air loosened, not because relief should change your spine, but because it does. She took her mother’s advice as if it were a vitamin she could dissolve under her tongue, and applied for the volunteer shift at the clinic, filling out a paper that had questions her body knew how to answer before her brain did. When she wrote her name in the square provided, she wrote it with the clean discipline of someone who had stopped wanting to see it everywhere.

The first day at the clinic, the room was a box painted a cheerful color that had known sadness and refused to let it be private. Tables had been pushed together to make islands, and pencils rolled off the edges and into hands that were used to catching things that tried to fall. The woman in charge was called Rasha and had a voice like a jacket that fit most people, and she introduced Rima as if she were a spoon, useful and ordinary and necessary. Twenty minutes later, six children held markers like weapons and declared that they would draw only monsters or only houses or only birds that had forgotten how to be afraid of people. Rima let them do it and did not tell them that tigers existed, because their monsters were complicated enough, and because she had promised herself that she would not feed her story to anyone who had not asked for a second serving.

A girl named Mira—who had a hairclip bitten into the shape of a star and a habit of measuring everything by the distance between her eyebrows and the person speaking—drew a cat with teeth like triangles from a math book and then told Rima that the cat loved lemons. Another boy, Ayman, made a city out of squares and then colored the sky black because he had been reprimanded by a cousin for using blue on a Thursday once and had decided never to do it again. Rima asked them what they wanted to name a street and they named it after a teacher, and after a soccer player, and after a grandmother who had once stopped a car with her hand because it had offended her crossing. When they wrote small sentences under their drawings, Rima tried not to make suggestions that would turn those sentences into versions of herself, and she failed once or twice and recovered by keeping her mouth busy with agreeing noises instead of edits.

On the walk home, she passed a door that had been painted with flowers by a hand that had never seen a flower and still managed to get the insistence correct. A man sitting on a chair that belonged to the street asked if the clinic paid in cash or in gratitude and whether he could apply if it was the second, and she told him to try and he saluted her with an orange soda. She realized that for the first time in weeks she was not walking toward the cinema or away from it, and the relief had in it the faintest sting, because the room without the crate had become a map pinned to her ribs. She went anyway, because absence is a sculpture you should not leave in the dark too long, and stood where the square of pacing had gradually faded into the general rumor of concrete, and let that mild grief have a minute.

Hadi called to ask if she could sit in on a session where a man who had learned generosity in public and cruelty in private wanted to practice dull kindness. The request was specific in a way that made her respect him more than she had the day before, because good work has names for its parts. The men arrived in the wrong order and sat in chairs that had not been designed for the bodies they brought into the room, and Hadi stood with his hands in front of him as if carrying an invisible bowl that needed to be kept level. The man with the dimples who made women forgive him before he had asked them to spoke first and said he was exhausted by his own talent for escape, and the one who was built like a cupboard and had learned to store emotion rather than display it said he had begun to hate Thursday nights because there was too much expectation piled on top of a beer. Rima watched Hadi do the work of refusing to be their savior and instead be their calendar, and it made something behind her sternum stretch pleasantly and then warn her not to be simple.

After the session a man lingered and told Rima a story about his mother making cheese by boiling milk until it became reason, and confessed that when she died he began to eat plastic-wrapped slices because grief had taught him to reject effort. Hadi walked her out and they leaned against a wall that had collected twenty years of conversations and agreed that men were children and women were children and everyone was a child and that judging that fact was less useful than planning nap times. He asked if she had written the paragraph about hands he had been waiting to read and when she said yes he kissed the top of her head without warning in the way a brother does when he remembers to be tender. She shoved him away gently and they grinned at their own competence at not complicating the moment, and then both of them fell quiet because the temptation had been there and naming it felt like letting a door blow shut.

The tiger became a rumor in the city’s mouth rather than a headline, and Rima was grateful for the demotion. The iron door acquired new messages—someone had drawn a fish large enough to swallow the word predator, and someone else had written a phone number and the words I CAN FIX ANY FAN, and below it a third person had added IF YOU CAN FIX MY MOTHER-IN-LAW YOU ARE A GENIUS. She took a photograph of the door because her memory had begun to misbehave in small ways and she wanted proof that cities are jokes told by committees, and she sent the photograph to Maya because editors can be rehabilitated into friends if everyone is careful. Maya sent back a sentence about doors being mouths and Rima rolled her eyes fondly and saved it for later theft.

Karim called at an hour the hills consider private and asked in his straightforward voice if she could come up on Friday without asking questions on the phone. She said yes because people who manage animals with their hands seldom dramatize logistics unnecessarily, and because yes was the kind of obedience she had learned to enjoy in this context. On the road north, the air decided to be clean enough for her to smell what the factories contributed, and she found herself angry and fond in the same breath, which is to say she was loyal to the place. At the sanctuary, the light slipped between leaves the way a phrase slips between friends at a table without needing to make sense to everyone, and Karim met her at the gate with an expression that carried both pride and a request to be told he was wrong if he was wrong.

Mishmish had an abrasion on her shoulder that looked worse than it was, the result of a quarrel with a branch that had stood its ground. Karim had decided to encourage the animal to present it voluntarily to a hand and had a plan that involved patience and tuna and the careful management of who watched whom. He asked Rima not to speak for an hour, which was an insult she accepted gladly, and showed her where to stand so that the tiger could see her without feeling seen. The animal approached in arcs that would have embarrassed geometry teachers, and each time Karim did nothing until doing something would not be a betrayal. When the head came close enough that Rima could see the particular constellation of whisker-spots that had become her favorite proof of existence, she remembered the corridor and the iron door and the water made into bricks of ice, and she felt at the same time the arrogance of her old wanting and the sobriety of this new arrangement where her wanting had to be smaller than the animal’s comfort. The tuna did its loyal work, which is to say it made everything easier without pretending to be holy, and Karim laid a hand briefly, a touch so light that it was barely an admission, and Rima did not cry because the economy of that contact forbade squandered reactions.

On the drive back she stopped at a roadside stand where figs were being lied about and could not decide which lie she preferred—Rashaya or Tyre—and bought both, which is a decision money will let you pretend is principled. The man selling them had the eyes of someone who had forgiven two sons and a brother and was now bored, and he asked if she had ever considered opening a shop because her face looked like it would do well with customers. She told him she had opened a whole building once and it had not gone well, and he told her he had once opened a marriage and it had done fine until it needed servicing, and the tone of the exchange made her laugh, which made him give her an extra two figs because men like to be rewarded for humor they did not plan.

Salma’s health made a small joke and then apologized for it. She fainted in the supermarket by the aisle with the olive oil and fell against a display of biscuits that scattered themselves like money, and when she came to she had one soft cookie in her hand and the certainty that the body can embarrass you in public and keep your dignity anyway. Rima met her at the clinic and watched a nurse half her age take her mother’s blood pressure with the kind of seriousness that prevented Rima from making any jokes, and when a young doctor with a haircut that had been chosen by a mother said fulminations of dehydration, they nodded as if he had described a minor character in a soap opera. The bureaucracy wrapped them in its slow embrace and asked them to sit and then to stand and then to sit again from a different direction, and Rima filled a form for her mother because Salma had refused to wear her glasses because they were ugly, and she found that writing her mother’s date of birth on a paper she would not keep made her feel strangely proprietary about the way time passed through that body.

They bought the prescribed water and salt and sugar as if they were ingredients for a dessert and took a taxi home because sometimes taxis were better than the bus when the day had already taken more than its fair share and you were in no mood to measure yourself against the city's arithmetic. In the kitchen, lemon halves sat like witnesses again while Salma insisted on making a dish that required more attention than a body should give after falling, and Rima did not argue because the hierarchy here was ancient and the stove could be its altar. When Salma sat down finally, she told a story about a cousin who had fainted in a wedding dress and been so grateful for the excuse to sit that she had fallen again in the same place the next day, and they laughed not because they were cruel but because the story had been told to them at exactly the right time.

The boy with the camera appeared at the cinema wearing a shirt that had been ironed so enthusiastically it had become a different shirt, and told Rima that he had been offered an internship at a paper that pretended to be more important than it was and that he might take it because he had discovered that being poor was wasting his good angles. He asked if he could write about the tiger without telling people where she was and whether he should mention her name and whether if he did his mother would stop thinking he was unserious, and Rima told him that he could write about the thing he had seen as long as he did not use it as a mirror for his feelings unless he did it better than most people did. He promised to try and she believed him because believing boys when they promised to try was a muscle she exercised carefully but regularly, and she told him that if the paper edited his piece until it became a stranger he should print it himself on bad paper and hang it in his kitchen and make people read it before he allowed them to sit.

The landlord’s sister began to put rugs in the corridor and rules on the door and told Rima that slippers were required because bare feet carried gossip into private spaces. She arranged six plants like a congregation and watered them with a measuring cup in a way that made Rima fear for their will to live, and when Rima suggested that plants preferred neglect to suffocation the woman made a face that suggested she doubted experts and had a PhD in household convictions. Abu Fadi watched the two of them with the glee of a man watching two cats negotiate a map and warned his sister, in the voice of a man who had learned not to step directly into the road unless prepared to be run over, that Rima’s rules were already written on the wall of the city. In the end, they negotiated a ceasefire where the plants would be allowed and the slippers suggested and the corridor would be swept every other day by anyone who found it dirty first, which in practice meant Rima most mornings because she woke earlier than most people in the building and hated stepping over crumbs.

Maya asked her to write a column that would exist once a month and not apologize to itself for starting fresh each time, and Rima asked for permission to sometimes write about nothing and was surprised when the answer was yes. She wrote the first about ironing, and about the way heat and pressure—applied to cloth or to a story—could be either an act of care or of cruelty depending on the wrist. She confessed that she did not iron and would always rather hang something near a window and let the weather and time collaborate, and then she wrote a sentence about her father ironing his shirts while watching soccer with the sound off because commentary is a form of invasion, and she kept the sentence when she had the urge to cut it because cutting would have been an act of cowardice disguised as perfectionism. The column landed quietly like a plate in a kitchen that is already loud, and three women wrote to tell her that they ironed only when their mothers visited, and one man wrote to say that he ironed everything because his mother had not visited in twenty years.

Ghida, whose room had begun to feel like a country with rules you could respect without having to pledge allegiance to anything, asked Rima what she had wanted to say to her father for a decade and had not, and when Rima said she wanted to ask him if he had loved exactly one person in his life fiercely and whether that person had been a woman or a version of himself that had played tennis, Ghida nodded as if the ridiculousness of the question was not an offense but a requirement. Rima went to the graveyard on a morning that smelled like rain had insulted a rock and placed a bottle of water near the stone because she could not bear to come empty-handed, and she spoke aloud knowing that stones do not answer but they do witness. She told upturned dust that she had done a ridiculous thing and returned it to its proper place, and that she had learned that proper places are sentences that need to be negotiated constantly, and she thanked a man who could not hear for the three rules he had given her: do not look at the ball, do not look at yourself, swing. Then she sat on a low wall and refused to narrate her own sincerity because some scenes die under the weight of language.

A storm threatened and then decided it preferred the next valley and left the city with fast clouds and a mood. The second checkpoint acquired a new soldier who was not good at his job in the way that made him kind because he did not know yet where he was supposed to be cruel. Noura lost a battle with a map and won something more important with a phone call that made three men bend in three offices, and she sent Rima a photograph of a tortoise who had decided to be a philosopher and a monkey who had decided to be a thief of pens. Karim sent a message that simply read rain came and we found out where the roof was lying about itself, and Rima sent back a promise of money because promises are how people who are not physically present pretend to be helpful. She went to see Uncle Sami at the ice place because loyalty is a map too, and bought a small bag of ice even though the weather did not require it, and listened to him talk about a niece who had taken a job in a country where people did not shout and had written home that the quiet hurt her ears.

At the clinic, Ayman apologized to his Thursday rules and used blue for sky and then felt guilty and asked Rima if he had betrayed his cousin. She told him that color was not the kind of fidelity anyone should be testing, and he thought about it and drew a bicycle with the perspective all wrong and told her the man who sold the bicycle refused to believe that the boy buying it had not stolen the money, and she asked him to write that down and he did in letters that were all elbows. Mira decided that the lemon-cat deserved a friend and drew a bird with teeth and wrote under it that it only ate seeds because teeth were a decoration and not a plan, and Rima told her she should get paid for the sentence one day. When she walked from the clinic to the bus, she saw three men unsuccessfully pretending not to like the rain and one woman successfully pretending not to like the rain, and she took a picture of the pavement because the tiny puddles had become her favorite city—clear, bordered, temporary.

Hadi and she made a new practice of swimming very early when the beach was half-empty and the lifeguards were bleary-eyed and kind. They did not talk much in the water because breath has better uses there, and when they sat after in the warm with coffee he told her that his father had begun to make jokes again and he did not know if this meant he was healing or cowering. She told him that laughter could be both a rock and a river, and he told her that sentence was ugly and probably true, and that Ghida had asked him to try not laughing for an hour in his next session and he was terrified of discovering that everything he said without laughter was a complaint. They planned a small celebration for his first five paying clients and decided to call it a lunch and not a ceremony because men deserve to be fed rather than applauded, and because Lebanon had spent too much applause on the wrong afternoons.

The cousin of the cinema owner persisted with his letters, and in one he included an invoice for air that had been, in his opinion, consumed excessively by Rima and her fans. Abu Fadi responded by installing a small sign in the lobby that read AIR FREE TODAY ONLY and took a photograph of it and sent it to the cousin and to Rima with a string of laughing emojis that looked like pills. Rima printed the photograph and taped it above her desk to remind herself to be stupid in public occasionally, and she wrote a paragraph that began with the absurdity and ended with a serious thought about the commons. Maya told her to move it from the beginning to the sixth paragraph and to stop hiding her thesis in jokes and to risk earnestness earlier, and Rima sulked for an hour and then did it and the piece grew bones where previously there had been cartilage.

In the sanctuary, a hyena arrived with eyes like long questions and a history that had to be discovered backwards. Karim showed Rima how an animal names its square by stepping into it with the same foot first, and how patience is a verb with teeth, and how even the laziest afternoon can require the full strength of two hands if you are doing it right. She watched him teach a young volunteer how to hold a bucket as if it were fragile when it was made of plastic and then explain that everything should be handled that way, not because it might break but because it might resist being used. When she told him he sounded like a book he said he had never liked books because they stayed where you left them, and she told him that some of them moved at night and he made the particular face men make when forced to admit they have been charmed against their will.

The boy with the camera wrote his piece and it appeared in a column that had once mattered and still pretended to, and it was good enough to make Rima jealous and respectful in equal measure. He did not mention names and he did not claim knowledge he did not possess, and he stopped the piece at exactly the right place and did not add a sentimental sentence about hope, which made her want to buy him a pair of shoes. He came to see her with the paper folded to his paragraph and a look on his face like a person who has found a coin on the ground that turned out to be gold-plated, and she told him to keep the clipping in a book and not on his wall so that only thieves of books would steal it. He said the editor had asked him to find a second animal and he had said no, and she told him he had saved himself three bad years with that one small refusal.

Salma’s neighbor’s forgetting began to invite strangers into their hallway in the form of cousins with opinions, and Rima practiced the art of smiling at people whose presence made the apartment smaller. She learned to avoid the hours when the kitchen became a parliament and instead brought food at times when chewing would interrupt debate, and she learned that three people could get through an awkward afternoon by shelling peas, and she learned that if you sing three lines badly and then repeat them you can put a sorrow to sleep temporarily. Salma herself rediscovered flirting with life, which is to say she bought new curtains with flowers that were too big and scolded them for being showy and hung them anyway, and she informed Rima that she would not attend any event where people clapped for her daughter because clapping made her nervous, but that she would stand near the door and take in the air like a participant.
