She told him that color was not the kind of fidelity anyone should be testing, and he thought about it and drew a bicycle with the perspective all wrong and told her the man who sold the bicycle refused to believe that the boy buying it had not stolen the money, and she asked him to write that down and he did in letters that were all elbows. Mira decided that the lemon-cat deserved a friend and drew a bird with teeth and wrote under it that it only ate seeds because teeth were a decoration and not a plan, and Rima told her she should get paid for the sentence one day. When she walked from the clinic to the bus, she saw three men unsuccessfully pretending not to like the rain and one woman successfully pretending not to like the rain, and she took a picture of the pavement because the tiny puddles had become her favorite city—clear, bordered, temporary.

Hadi and she made a new practice of swimming very early when the beach was half-empty and the lifeguards were bleary-eyed and kind. They did not talk much in the water because breath has better uses there, and when they sat after in the warm with coffee he told her that his father had begun to make jokes again and he did not know if this meant he was healing or cowering. She told him that laughter could be both a rock and a river, and he told her that sentence was ugly and probably true, and that Ghida had asked him to try not laughing for an hour in his next session and he was terrified of discovering that everything he said without laughter was a complaint. They planned a small celebration for his first five paying clients and decided to call it a lunch and not a ceremony because men deserve to be fed rather than applauded, and because Lebanon had spent too much applause on the wrong afternoons.

The cousin of the cinema owner persisted with his letters, and in one he included an invoice for air that had been, in his opinion, consumed excessively by Rima and her fans. Abu Fadi responded by installing a small sign in the lobby that read AIR FREE TODAY ONLY and took a photograph of it and sent it to the cousin and to Rima with a string of laughing emojis that looked like pills. Rima printed the photograph and taped it above her desk to remind herself to be stupid in public occasionally, and she wrote a paragraph that began with the absurdity and ended with a serious thought about the commons. Maya told her to move it from the beginning to the sixth paragraph and to stop hiding her thesis in jokes and to risk earnestness earlier, and Rima sulked for an hour and then did it and the piece grew bones where previously there had been cartilage.

In the sanctuary, a hyena arrived with eyes like long questions and a history that had to be discovered backwards. Karim showed Rima how an animal names its square by stepping into it with the same foot first, and how patience is a verb with teeth, and how even the laziest afternoon can require the full strength of two hands if you are doing it right. She watched him teach a young volunteer how to hold a bucket as if it were fragile when it was made of plastic and then explain that everything should be handled that way, not because it might break but because it might resist being used. When she told him he sounded like a book he said he had never liked books because they stayed where you left them, and she told him that some of them moved at night and he made the particular face men make when forced to admit they have been charmed against their will.

The boy with the camera wrote his piece and it appeared in a column that had once mattered and still pretended to, and it was good enough to make Rima jealous and respectful in equal measure. He did not mention names and he did not claim knowledge he did not possess, and he stopped the piece at exactly the right place and did not add a sentimental sentence about hope, which made her want to buy him a pair of shoes. He came to see her with the paper folded to his paragraph and a look on his face like a person who has found a coin on the ground that turned out to be gold-plated, and she told him to keep the clipping in a book and not on his wall so that only thieves of books would steal it. He said the editor had asked him to find a second animal and he had said no, and she told him he had saved himself three bad years with that one small refusal.

Salma’s neighbor’s forgetting began to invite strangers into their hallway in the form of cousins with opinions, and Rima practiced the art of smiling at people whose presence made the apartment smaller. She learned to avoid the hours when the kitchen became a parliament and instead brought food at times when chewing would interrupt debate, and she learned that three people could get through an awkward afternoon by shelling peas, and she learned that if you sing three lines badly and then repeat them you can put a sorrow to sleep temporarily. Salma herself rediscovered flirting with life, which is to say she bought new curtains with flowers that were too big and scolded them for being showy and hung them anyway, and she informed Rima that she would not attend any event where people clapped for her daughter because clapping made her nervous, but that she would stand near the door and take in the air like a participant.

The city’s light shifted into its autumn shape and the evenings became a way of forgiving the day for what it had done. The Corniche filled with men who declared that cold had arrived while being wrong and with women who refused to bring sweaters out of principle, and the fishermen pretended not to notice tourists pretending to know anything about fish. The iron door acquired a new piece of graffiti in a tender hand that read WE ARE TIRED OF BEING BRAVE TRY BEING SAFE FOR A WEEK, and Rima did not paint over it because it sounded like a prayer a person who had run out of the proper ones might try. She traced the curve of the S with her thumb as if it would fix something, and then she went upstairs and wrote about a day when safety had been an unremarkable noun, and she sent it to Maya and Maya wrote back that the unremarkable is the only revolution she believed in this year.

When the storm finally came, it came with a stance, shoulders square, hands open, as if ready to argue anyone out of their sunshine. Trees popped with the sound of equalities asserted and then broken, and the street briefly became a river where cigarette butts swam bravely before drowning. The ceiling of the back room at the cinema revealed a line of betrayal, and Rima arranged bowls under it as if placing instruments in an orchestra and listened to their different pitches with a satisfaction that felt inappropriate but was not, because the music meant she could act. She called the number under I CAN FIX ANY FAN and a man arrived with a toolbox and a temper and looked at the leak like a personal insult, and he climbed a ladder with the grace of an old acrobat and made it stop long enough for the storm to forget to insist.

After the storm, the city did what it always did after deciding to live through another indignity: it dried its hair in the sun and pretended it had never been bothered. The clinic was full of children who had discovered puddles and learned to jump without the permission of any adult, and Rasha had to pretend to scold them because the floor had become a map of wet footprints that would turn into a hazard if not admired briefly and then removed. Mira drew a bird that had decided to wear a raincoat and gave it a name too long to fit under the picture, and Ayman tried to describe thunder without using the word thunder and failed beautifully. Rima took their pages home and put them in a folder marked Stories That Do Not Ask For Me, and she felt the sweetness of keeping things that did not need her to make sense.

Hadi’s group learned to sit without filling silences with weather, and a man who had never spoken about his divorce because his preferred story about himself did not include any acts of being left said slowly that he had been told to be strong and had decided to be useful instead, and that this had ended badly for everyone. They sat with that until the clock demanded they pay attention to it instead, and after the session Hadi and Rima ate shawarma standing up because stools are timid furniture and some decisions are best made while leaning. He told her that he had turned down a client who wanted him to help with a speech to impress investors because he had asked what the man wanted out of life and the man had said applause, and Rima put her hand on the back of his neck briefly because it was a part of the body that respects small encouragements, and then she removed it because the air between them was theirs and she did not want to spend it improperly.

Night returned to being evidence rather than a threat, and Rima found that she could read after nine without her mind staging a small refusal. She opened a book of letters between two women who had died before Lebanon taught her to count time in outages and admired the way they were unashamed of loving each other’s sentences. She made tea that tasted like a compromise between mint and the idea of mint, and she wrote a paragraph about repair that did not try to be larger than the objects it described. She thought briefly of the tiger and then did not, which felt like progress and also like disloyalty, and she allowed herself to believe that both could be true and she could be permitted to sleep.

The next morning, she woke to the smell of bread that was not her own and realized that the landlord’s sister had baked manakish in a pan that had seen battle and was now a veteran, and the woman had placed one at Rima’s door with a note that read SORRY FOR THE RUGS I WILL REDUCE THEM BY ONE. Rima took the bread and warmed it and ate it with her fingers because food wants to be touched, and she stood at the threshold chewing and thinking that the world would be easier if every apology arrived with thyme. She went back to her desk, opened the document titled In Care Of, and wrote, for the first time without hesitation, a page that began not with a tiger or with a mother or with a man who had learned to be a different kind of useful, but with a towel hung carefully on a chair to dry in a room where a leak had been persuaded to pause. She wrote until the generator decided to flirt with her anger again, and then she wrote a little more in the dark because stubbornness can be as holy as a plan when you are honest about it.
